title: Figure size (e.g., width) not respected in LaTeX output when using figure-md
body:
### Describe the bug

**context**
When I do compile a book using pdflatex with figures, using `figure` gets the correct size in the exported latex file, but using `figure-md` doesn't.

**expectation**
For example, I would expect the generated latex to have a [width=4in] in the \sphinxincludegraphics clause.

**bug**
There is no bracket element in the \sphinxincludegraphics clause.

**problem**
This is a problem for people exporting books to LaTeX using the most Markdown-ish code possible (using figure-md instead of figure).


### Reproduce the bug

Create a book, and write code similar to:

```
:::{figure} _static/images/image.png
:name: fig_image
:width: 4in
My nice caption
:::
```

it correctly generates:

```
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[width=4in]{{image}.png}
\caption{My nice caption}\label{\detokenize{index:fig-image}}\end{figure}
```

now replace with:

```
:::{figure-md} fig_image
:width: 4in
![](_static/images/image.png)

My nice caption
:::
```

it incorrectly generates:

```
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{image}.png}
\caption{My nice caption}\label{\detokenize{index:fig-image}}\end{figure}
```

(without the width).

### List your environment

```
Jupyter Book      : 0.15.1
External ToC      : 0.3.1
MyST-Parser       : 0.18.1
MyST-NB           : 0.17.1
Sphinx Book Theme : 1.0.1
Jupyter-Cache     : 0.5.0
NbClient          : 0.5.13
```

title: jupyter notebook code cell output has a indent in latex pdf.
body:
### Describe the bug

Recently, I re-installed Jupyter Book(v0.15.1) and created a pdf based on latex and jupyter notebook.
However, unlike before, code cell output is automatically indented. (Markdown cell output is fine.)
An example of a problem caused by this: 
I am using IPython.display.Markdown with Markdown Cell for writing markdown, and the above indentation causes a problem that the starting positions of markdown text lines are not matched each other.

I think default of indent of somthing is changed. I am looking for that in code. Is there someone who can help me ?

### Reproduce the bug

1. Import : from IPython.display import Markdown as md
2. Write markdown using markdown cell and IPython.display.Markdown as follow:
Cell1[code cell] : md("- blah blah")
Cell2[markdown cell] : - blah blah
3. Print pdf based on latex 


### List your environment

Jupyter Book : 0.15.1
Jupyter notebook : 6.5.2

title: full-width setting in single document mode behaving not as expected
body: ### Describe the bug **context** I'm generating an HTML using jupyter-book in single document mode, i.e. https://jupyterbook.org/en/stable/structure/toc.html?highlight=single%20document#build-an-article-from-a-single-file I'd like to set a markdown cell to use the "full-width", i.e. https://jupyterbook.org/en/stable/content/layout.html?highlight=full%20width#full-width-markdown-content **expectation** I expected the cell to use the full width of the page in the HTML to display the content. **bug** But instead, it's only uses the right-hand side of the page to extend the content in `full-width` mode. **problem** This is a problem for people using single page mode, as 1) there's a waste of space on the left hand side, 2) its asymmetrical, and 3) people generating single page documents would expect that using the full-width include the full width of the browser. ### Reproduce the bug * Create a jupyter notebook. * Create a markdown cell with content * Precede the content with ````{div} full-width * Append the content with ```` * Save the file * Generate a single document page with jupyter book by calling `jupyter book build NAME.ipynb` where NAME is the filename of your newly created notebook. * Open the generated HTML in a brower ### List your environment Jupyter Book : 0.13.0 External ToC : 0.2.4 MyST-Parser : 0.15.2 MyST-NB : 0.13.2 Sphinx Book Theme : 0.3.3 Jupyter-Cache : 0.4.3 NbClient : 0.5.13

title: Code cells are rendering without style;
body:
### Describe the bug

The code cells in my notebook are rendering without style when I build the book. The entire cell has the same font and color, it is written in plain black. I expected the code snippet to be similar to the ones on the Jupyter book website, i.e. with bold and green import, a different style for commenting ... 

Here is what I have : 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/72134287/216621421-aecef4f0-df5b-4b37-adb2-7d8bb3008d25.png)

Here is what I expected : 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/72134287/216621133-76e5ba7c-7d47-48a1-9d8d-022f98e5fce1.png)

Is there a reason for this ? How can I fix it? 

Thanks in advance. 

### Reproduce the bug

It happened on build time, I don't know how to reproduce it.

title: Error using jupyter-book (mach-o file, but is an incompatible architecture (have 'x86_64', need 'arm64'))
body:
### Describe the bug

When I try to build my jupyter-book, I get an error. Other people working on the same git-repo don't get the same error. I am working on a M1 Mac and have installed python through homebrew. 

This is the error message I get

```console
$ jupyter-book build mybook
sphinx.errors.ExtensionError: Could not import extension myst_nb (exception: dlopen(PATH1, 0x0002): tried: 'PATH1' (mach-o file, but is an incompatible architecture (have 'x86_64', need 'arm64')), 'PATH2' (no such file), 'PATH1' (mach-o file, but is an incompatible architecture (have 'x86_64', need 'arm64')))
```




### Reproduce the bug

1. Use a M1 Mac
2. (Install brew if not installed)
3. Open terminal of choice
4. Write "brew install python"
5. Write "pip install jupyter-book"
6. Write "jupyter build <your-jupyter-book>"

### List your environment

Ironically, I cannot even use jupyter-book --version, as I get the same error. 

jupyter-book-0.13.1

title: sphinx config does not transfer all atributes from _config.yml to conf.py
body:
### Describe the bug

**context**
When I do `jupyter-book config sphinx path`.

**expectation**
I expected an identical jupyter book, but built w/ sphinx

**bug**
A few attributes are not carried over, including `html_title`, `author`, `html_logo`

### Reproduce the bug

Run `jupyter-book config sphinx path` on an existing project with a custom name and authors

### List your environment

```
Jupyter Book      : 0.13.0
External ToC      : 0.2.4
MyST-Parser       : 0.18.1
MyST-NB           : 0.17.1

title: Incompatible with docutils 0.19 ??
body:
### Describe the bug

**context**
When I try to build a book.

**expectation**
I expected the book to be built

**bug**
But instead, then it happens an exception is raised
Here's an error message I ran into...

```console
$ jupyter-book build mybook


Running Sphinx v4.5.0
[etoc] Changing master_doc to 'intro'

Exception occurred:
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 800, in resolve
    raise VersionConflict(dist, req).with_context(dependent_req)
pkg_resources.ContextualVersionConflict: (docutils 0.19 (/opt/conda/lib/python3.10/site-packages), Requirement.parse('docutils<0.18,>=0.14'), {'Sphinx'})

```

**problem**
Cannot build books.


### Reproduce the bug

Install jupyter book as per instructions on JupyterLab with python 3.10.

### List your environment

Python 3.10
Ubuntu 22.04
JupyterLab 3.4.8

title: Unable to run the project locally
body:
### Describe the bug

According to the docs, after cloning the project you should run

```console
$ python -m pip install -e .[testing,code_style]
```

But I get `no matches found: .[testing,code_style]`

### Reproduce the bug

1. Follow the instructions in the docs https://jupyterbook.org/en/stable/contribute/intro.html#getting-started
2. Check if it works

### List your environment

Python 3.10.4
OS: Ubuntu

title: When viewing a page (html), the page's table of contents misidentifies the currently viewed section
body:
### Describe the bug

**context**
When I load a section of a page (e.g. `page.html#section-name`) in a browser

**expectation**
I expect the page's table of contents to show me viewing that section (i.e. highlight it and show any subsections)

**bug**
But instead, the previous section shows up as being viewed (unless i'm viewing the first section of the page).

**problem**
This is a problem for people browsing a page because it makes the table contents pretty confusing
1. if i click on a section, i don't get to see what its subsections are
2. and relatedly, if the previous section has subsections, it shows me those. 

in short, this can get pretty confusing when exploring a page's sections and subsections via the table of contents

it seems like the mechanism for how jupyter book infers the currently viewed section needs to be adjusted. It seems to be barely missing the threshold for recognizing the current section (i.e., if i scroll down a smidge, the toc updates and is correct).

maybe this is an issue with the sphinx theme or html template? 

### Reproduce the bug

1. Visit this page in the docs (for example): 
   - https://jupyterbook.org/en/latest/start/create.html
3. Under "Contents" on the right, click on "Content Files"
4. Observe that...
   1. in the table of contents, "Content Files" isn't highlighted or expanded"
   2. instead, the previous section is highlighted with its subsections
   3. to get the toc to show "Content Files" and its subsections, you have to scroll down a little

![Screen Shot 2022-08-31 at 3 28 01 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/908970/187766376-10ee8dd6-1b8d-4e7c-9c07-318313afb8f9.png)

### List your environment

_No response_

title: Incorrect instructions for Plausible.io Analytics
body:
### Describe the bug

**context**
In [this section of the docs](https://jupyterbook.org/en/stable/advanced/html.html?highlight=Plausible#enable-google-analytics), it seems that it's possible to add Plausible.io analytics:

> To use other analytics services, like Plausible analytics, you should link the relevant libraries via the instructions in Custom CSS or JavaScript.

However to use Plausible, what actually needs to be injected into the `<head>` is a bit of html:

```
<script defer data-domain="website.domain.com" src="https://plausible.io/js/plausible.js"></script>
```

The linked section in JupyterBook docs even says:

> Any files that end in **.css or .js** in this folder will automatically be copied into your built book HTML and linked in the header of each page.

**expectation**
I expected the docs to describe how to inject html into the <head>, but it only talks about css and js.

Is there a way to inject html into the head of every page? I know about the `extra_footer` that I could use in my `_config.yml` file, is there an `extra_head`? 


### Reproduce the bug

N/A - this is a question/deficiency in the docs.

### List your environment

macOS 12.5

```
▶ jupyter-book --version
Jupyter Book      : 0.13.0
External ToC      : 0.2.4
MyST-Parser       : 0.15.2
MyST-NB           : 0.13.2
Sphinx Book Theme : 0.3.2
Jupyter-Cache     : 0.4.3
NbClient          : 0.5.13
```

title: WARNING: duplicate label structure:index, other instance in
body: Issue fixed.

title: Documentation: Card links broken
body:
### Describe the bug

**context**

Rendered documentation has broken links (.md in URL instead of .html)

**expectation**

I cannot reproduce this on a local build with current master, however I'm building the same commit as Read the Docs. It's probably due to a dependency that has changed, but I'm unable to figure out which?

**bug**

To be clear, it's these cards

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/374612/183104611-5607d8ce-f2c7-4f4e-a07a-922a9f9018c5.png)


### Reproduce the bug

title: Cant use the same document for multiple chapters/sections
body:
### Describe the bug

**context**
In my _toc.yml file i made multiple chapters with sections, and i want to show specific sides (.ipynb) multiple times in different sections or chapters. But instead it displays me an error while building.

**expectation**
I expected that that i can view my .ipynb file parallel in different sections

**bug**
But instead i got an error:
Here's an error message I ran into...

```console
The Table of Contents file is malformed: document file used multiple times: 'visualization/ipynb/scatter'
You may need to migrate from the old format, using:

        jupyter-book toc migrate C:\Users\JohnT\GithubProjects\data-science-jupyter-book\_toc.yml -o C:\Users\JohnT\GithubProjects\data-science-jupyter-book\_toc.yml
```



### Reproduce the bug

There are two ways to reproduce:
1. clone my repo with the dev branch and build it [Dev](https://github.com/JohnTrunix/data-science-jupyter-book/tree/dev)
or
1. build a new book
2. in your _toc.yml create two sections and add the same file to both sections
3. build it

```

title: Can't have a toc link without title
body:
### Describe the bug

I would like to have a file without title (no header # ...) but that would appear in the toc. To this end, I add a title in the toc :
```
chapters:
    - file: myfile
      title: mytitle
```
However, I get:
```
WARNING: toctree contains reference to document myfile that doesn't have a title: no link will be generated
```
Any idea?

1. Create a file without title
2. Add it to the toc, specifying a title
3. The file does not appear in the toc

title: (v0.13.0) Clicking on contents (right sidebar), subsections of previous section opens in sidebar instead of clicked section.
body: ### Describe the bug **context** When I click on section on sidebar. **expectation** I expected subsections of clicked section to unravel. **bug** But instead subsections of previous section unravels. **problem** This is a problem for people navigating the book using the contents sidebar. ### Reproduce the bug 1. Install jupyter-book 0.13.0 on virtual env. 2. Create new book, e.g. https://jupyterbook.org/en/stable/start/your-first-book.html 3. Create many sections and many subsections (randomly adding `##` and `###`). 4. Click around the contents side bar on the right. Blow I'm clicking "Sample roles and directive", but the "What is MyST" is unraveling instead. ### List your environment local environment: ``` Jupyter Book : 0.13.0 External ToC : 0.2.4 MyST-Parser : 0.15.2 MyST-NB : 0.13.2 Sphinx Book Theme : 0.3.2 Jupyter-Cache : 0.4.3 NbClient : 0.5.13 ``` Not sure about the environment in github actions, but the deployed book built using tox and github actions also have this bug.

title: Bokeh plots do not render with cell tags
body:

**context**
Bokeh plots do not render when pages contain cell tags example `remove-cell` or `remove-input`.  This happens regardless of where the cell tags are, even if they are not within the cell that contains the bokeh plot.

**expectation**

**bug**
Bokeh plots do not render, the below error is seen upon console inspection.

Bokeh: ERROR: Unable to run BokehJS code because BokehJS library is missing

title: Latex regression tests are failing with Sphinx 4.5
body:
### Describe the bug

With Sphinx 4.5, our latex regression tests started failing. Here's @AakashGfude's diagnosis:

> the generated tex file here has an extra command `\sphinxstepscope` inserted in tex regression files. This change seems to have been introduced from `sphinx==4.5.0`. As `sphinx<=4.4.0` works fine. Let me see if I can find the reason for it being inserted, as we cant have separated regression files between the same sphinx major but different minor versions. 

### Reproduce the bug

Here's an example of a failing test from a recent PR: https://github.com/executablebooks/jupyter-book/runs/5745097945?check_suite_focus=true#step:7:78

### Actions

At the very least, we should update our regression tests to work with Sphinx 4.5.

A better long-term fix would be to target the latex regression tests so that they only target specific chunks of Latex, and are less brittle to random Sphinx output changes.

title: Jinja 3.1 is incompatible with Sphinx 3.5, and breaks Jupyter Book w/ this configuration
body:
### Describe the bug

Jinja recently released a minor version (`3.1`) that is incompatible with the latest `3.X` series in Sphinx. Here's the relevant issue:

- https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues/10291

So all of our 3.x tests are failing, and anybody that pins Jupyter Book to use Sphinx 3.x is going to run into this issue.

### What to do about it?

I can think of two things we could do to resolve this:

1. Pin `jinja` to `<3.1`. This isn't a long-term solution, because we do eventually want to be able to upgrade Jinja.
2. Pin `sphinx` to >= 4 (and drop our 3.x tests). This would prevent people from using Jupyter Book with Sphinx 3...though my suspicion is that this is a very uncommon use-case.
3. Wait/hope that Sphinx releases a patch release that fixes this. Though I'm not sure whether they intend to do so or not.

My intuition is that we should see if `3` happens quickly, and if it doesn't, then go with option `2` for our next release. Since Jupyter Book is closer to an end-user application, I think there is less of a potential problem deprecating things more aggressively. Curious if others have thoughts


### Reproduce the bug

Install Sphinx 3.5.4 and Jinja 3.1 and try to build something with Sphinx.

title: Including sphinx_book_theme in extensions breaks templates_path

labels.name: :label: sphinx-book-theme
labels.description: An issue related to the theme

body:
### Describe the bug

**context**
According to the [Sphinx Templating documentation](https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/templating.html), it is possible to override a theme template by placing a template with the same name in `templates_path`:

> Templates with the same name in the [templates_path](https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/configuration.html#confval-templates_path) override templates supplied by the selected theme.

**expectation**
By adding a local `_templates` directory to `templates_path`, one should be able to override the theme templates. If a template is not found in the local `_templates` directory, it should fall back to the theme template. In other words, adding the following to `_config.yml` should be harmless:

```
sphinx:
  config:
    templates_path: ['_templates']
```

**bug**
Instead it seems this causes Sphinx to no longer able to find the theme templates.

With the above config addition, I get:

```console
$ jupyter-book build mybook
...
Theme error:
An error happened in rendering the page intro.
Reason: TemplateNotFound('sidebar-logo.html')
```

I have narrowed the problem down to the fact that `sphinx_book_theme`, in addition to being used as the `html_theme`, is also included as an `extension`. I'm not too familiar with Sphinx, and am unsure why and if a theme should be included as an extension. However, the [documentation for sphinx_book_theme](https://sphinx-book-theme.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorials/get-started.html#) seems to indicate that it is sufficient with `html_theme="sphinx_book_theme"`.

### Reproduce the bug

1. Create a test book: `jupyter-book create mybook`
2. Append the following to `mybook/_config.yml`:
```
sphinx:
  config:
    templates_path: ['_templates']
```
3. Build the book:
```
$ jupyter-book build mybook
Running Jupyter-Book v0.12.2
Source Folder: /home/joh/Downloads/mybook
Config Path: /home/joh/Downloads/mybook/_config.yml
Output Path: /home/joh/Downloads/mybook/_build/html
Running Sphinx v4.4.0
[etoc] Changing master_doc to 'intro'
loading pickled environment... checking for /home/joh/Downloads/mybook/references.bib in bibtex cache... up to date
done
myst v0.15.2: MdParserConfig(renderer='sphinx', commonmark_only=False, enable_extensions=['colon_fence', 'dollarmath', 'linkify', 'substitution', 'tasklist'], dmath_allow_labels=True, dmath_allow_space=True, dmath_allow_digits=True, dmath_double_inline=False, update_mathjax=True, mathjax_classes='tex2jax_process|mathjax_process|math|output_area', disable_syntax=[], url_schemes=['mailto', 'http', 'https'], heading_anchors=None, heading_slug_func=None, html_meta=[], footnote_transition=True, substitutions=[], sub_delimiters=['{', '}'], words_per_minute=200)

Traceback (most recent call last):

    output = self.templates.render(templatename, ctx)
  File "/home/joh/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sphinx/jinja2glue.py", line 196, in render
    return self.environment.get_template(template).render(context)
  File "/home/joh/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/jinja2/environment.py", line 1291, in render
    self.environment.handle_exception()
  File "/home/joh/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/jinja2/environment.py", line 925, in handle_exception
    raise rewrite_traceback_stack(source=source)
  File "/home/joh/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sphinx/themes/basic/page.html", line 10, in top-level template code
    {%- extends "layout.html" %}
  File "/home/joh/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sphinx_book_theme/layout.html", line 7, in top-level template code

title: Jupyter Book can't compile using Github Workflow: "The 'black' distribution was not found and is required by the application"
body:
### Describe the bug

**context**
I have a [repository](https://github.com/whyjz/pejzero) with a couple of Notebooks that I want to render as HTML using Jupyter Book and Github Actions.

**expectation**
I have tested `jupyter book build ./jupyter-book` on my local machine, and it worked out well as expected.

**bug**
But when I apply the sample workflow using Github Actions, an error message shows and says 
`pkg_resources.DistributionNotFound: The 'black' distribution was not found and is required by the application`.
Here's the [full report of the error message on Github Actions](https://github.com/whyjz/pejzero/runs/5225413065?check_suite_focus=true).

Honestly, I am not sure whether this is a dependency issue or not, or whether this is a Jupyter Book issue or Sphinx's.

### Reproduce the bug

You can reproduce the bug by [re-running the Github Action job](https://github.com/whyjz/pejzero/runs/5225413065?check_suite_focus=true).

### List your environment

My local environment is 
```
Jupyter Book      : 0.12.1
External ToC      : 0.2.3
MyST-Parser       : 0.15.2
MyST-NB           : 0.13.1
Sphinx Book Theme : 0.1.10
Jupyter-Cache     : 0.4.3
NbClient          : 0.5.3
```
which worked well for compiling HTML. The `environment.yml` that Github Action uses is
```
name: jme

channels:
  - conda-forge
  - defaults
dependencies:
  - python=3.8
  - geopandas
  - h5py
  - jupyter-book=0.12
  - matplotlib
  - netcdf4
  - numpy
  - pandas
  - pip
  - rasterio
  - scipy
  - seaborn
  - sphinx=4.3.2
```
which gives the error message.

Thanks in advance for any thoughts you have...

title: No search results
body:
### Describe the bug

**context**
When I create any book and type into the search box.

**expectation**
I expected a page of search results to load.

**bug**
But instead the page loads with no results appearing.

In the generated search.html page there is a 

``` html
<div id="jb-print-docs-body" class="onlyprint">
```

When I delete that div, then search works as expected.

**problem**
This is a problem for people doing search because they can't.

```
jb create foo
jb build foo

title: No numbering when using parts
body:
### Describe the bug

**context**
When I do split my TOC into parts, the previously working numbering is gone.

**expectation**
I expected numbering to continue to exist after splitting TOC into parts.

**bug**
But instead all numbering is gone, despite still having the `numbering` setting set.


### Reproduce the bug

TOC that works for numbering:

```yml
format: jb-book
root: intro
options:
  numbered: true
chapters:
  - file: 01_uvis_on_pds
  - file: 02_pds_data_structure
  - file: 03_calibration
  - file: bibliography
  - file: Appendix1_Flatfielding
  - file: Appendix2
```

TOC that doesn't work:

```yml
format: jb-book
root: intro
options:
  numbered: true
parts:
  - caption: Part 1
    chapters:
      - file: 01_uvis_on_pds
      - file: 02_pds_data_structure
      - file: 03_calibration
      - file: bibliography
  - caption: Part 2
    chapters:
      - file: Appendix1_Flatfielding
      - file: Appendix2
```

### List your environment

# GH workflow install via requirements

> jupyter-book --version
Jupyter Book      : 0.12.1
External ToC      : 0.2.3
MyST-Parser       : 0.15.2
MyST-NB           : 0.13.1
Sphinx Book Theme : 0.1.10
Jupyter-Cache     : 0.4.3
NbClient          : 0.5.10

* Python 3.8
* OS:
  * Ubuntu
  * 20.04.3
  * LTS

GH workflow:
```yml
jobs:
  build-and-deploy-book:
    runs-on: ${{ matrix.os }}
    strategy:
      matrix:
        os: [ubuntu-latest]
        python-version: [3.8]
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v2

    # Install dependencies
    - name: Set up Python ${{ matrix.python-version }}
      uses: actions/setup-python@v1
      with:
        python-version: ${{ matrix.python-version }}
    - name: Install dependencies
      run: |
        pip install -r requirements.txt
        jupyter-book --version

    # Build the book
    - name: Build the book
      run: |
        jupyter-book build .

    # Deploy the book's HTML to gh-pages branch
    - name: GitHub Pages action
      uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v3
      with:
        github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
        publish_dir: _build/html
```

title: Non-deterministic Chapter/Section Numbering
body:
### Describe the problem

We are hosting the draft of a textbook here at [roboticsbook.org](https://www.roboticsbook.org/intro.html). The website is configured using a github action. However, sometimes the build produces chapter and section numbering in one way, and sometimes in another way. We would like it to be consistent so that chapters are numbered 1, 2, 3 etc. and sections are numbered 1.2, 1.3 etc.

I tried adding a `jupyter-book clean .` into the workflow [book.yml](https://github.com/gtbook/robotics/blob/main/.github/workflows/book.yml)  but obviously that did not help, as the action runner starts from a clean slate anyway.

I'm at a loss. Any help would be very welcome, as this issue impedes telling our (400!) enrolled students to look at sections in a consistent way :-/

### Link to your repository or website

https://github.com/gtbook/robotics

### Steps to reproduce

It is hard to reproduce without cloning the repo, because this happens on a GitHub push event. Every time we push, we don't know what will happen. 

### The version of Python you're using

3.8

### Your operating system

Runner on Github is latest ubuntu

### Versions of your packages

```bash
> jupyter-book --version
Jupyter Book      : 0.12.1
External ToC      : 0.2.3
MyST-Parser       : 0.15.2
MyST-NB           : 0.13.1
Sphinx Book Theme : 0.1.9
Jupyter-Cache     : 0.4.3
NbClient          : 0.5.9
```

### Additional context

title: Tex macros not rendering, also in documentation
body:
### Describe the problem Tex Macros are not working as expected, as far as I can tell. The example in the documentation does not appear to be rendering correctly, even within the online documentation. The documentation looks like [this](https://jupyterbook.org/advanced/sphinx.html#defining-tex-macros):
![Screen Shot 2022-01-07 at 4 28 39 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12434323/148609863-9789338c-6285-4a5a-9d43-bced7b7fa02c.png)
This does not look like the intended rendering. I get the same thing using the code from the documentation in my `_config.yml` file, specifically by adding this: ``` sphinx: config: mathjax3_config: TeX: Macros: "N": "\\mathbb{N}" "floor": ["\\lfloor#1\\rfloor", 1] "bmat" : ["\\left[\\begin{array}"] "emat" : ["\\end{array}\\right]"] ``` Note that I am using **mathjax3_config** (with the "3") here, which I think is required. It does correctly render using the math directive approach instead ``` ```{math} \newcommand\N{\mathbb{N}} \newcommand\floor[1]{\lfloor#1\rfloor} \newcommand{\bmat}{\left[\begin{array}} \newcommand{\emat}{\end{array}\right]} `````` ``` $$ A = \bmat{} 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 1\\ 3 & 2 \emat{},\ b=\bmat{} 2\\ 3 \\ 4\emat{},\ \gamma = 0.5 $$ ``` which generates output like this: So it looks like the `_config.yml` macros syntax has stopped working, including when the online documentation was generated. ### Python version 3.9 ### Operating system Mac OS 12 ### Package versions ``` Jupyter Book : 0.12.1 External ToC : 0.2.3 MyST-Parser : 0.15.2 MyST-NB : 0.13.1 Sphinx Book Theme : 0.1.9 Jupyter-Cache : 0.4.3 NbClient : 0.5.9 ```

title: Some config vars not passed from conf.py to sphinx
body:
### Describe the problem

The sphinx config variables 'html_logo' and 'html_secnumber_suffix' CAN be adjusted through _config.yml, but seem to be ignored when configured in conf.py (without _config.yml file).

### Link to your repository or website

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

1. in _config.yml:    # this works

```
sphinx:
  config:
    html_secnumber_suffix: "\u00a0\u00a0"     # just whitespace, no trailing period!!
    html_logo: "logo.png"
```

2. delete _config.yml and add in conf.py:    # this doesn't work

```
html_logo = 'logo.png'                           # logo isn't included
html_secnumber_suffix= '\u00a0\u00a0'      # trailing period still included!!
```

body:
Maintainer note: This is fixed in pydata-sphinx-theme >= v0.7.2 (see https://github.com/pydata/pydata-sphinx-theme/pull/509)

---

### Describe the problem

For example, in my MD file, add the following table and it will compile and fail (this is a table in the official documentation)
```
| source                                         | result                                   |
|------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------|
| `` Here is {ref}`my-fig-ref` ``               | Here is {ref}`my-fig-ref`               |
| `` Here is {ref}`My cool fig <my-fig-ref>` `` | Here is {ref}`My cool fig <my-fig-ref>`              |
| `` Here is [](my-fig-ref) ``               | Here is [](my-fig-ref)               |
| `` Here is [My cool fig](my-fig-ref) `` | Here is [My cool fig](my-fig-ref)              |
| `` Here is {numref}`my-fig-ref` ``            | Here is {numref}`my-fig-ref`            |
| `` Here is {numref}`Custom Figure %s text ` `` | Here is {numref}`Custom Figure %s text <my-fig-ref>` |

| header 1 | header 2 |

title: Why is my admonition color not displayed correctly
body:
### Describe the problem

I edited the book in Jupyter Notebook by following the official tutorial

But no matter how I adjust it, there's no way to get the right color, right

I added a tip level admonition with the following code
```markdown

```{admonition} my tips
:class: tip
Here's my tips

title: Builld does not recognize ToC changes to title attributes of files
body:
### Describe the problem

When I add or modify the `title` section of a `file` in `_toc.yml`, jupyterbook does not include this update when building the pages. When I modify the `title` section of a `url` entry jupytebook correctly recognizes this change when building pages and the updated title is in the newly built book. As a workaround I make updates to the url titles when I want the file titles to update and then undo the url title changes and build the book again (it seems like the URL title changes need to be in the same section as the file changes for the change to take place).

Similar older issue here https://github.com/executablebooks/jupyter-book/issues/478


### Link to your repository or website

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

This is what the relevant part of my toc file looks like:

```
format: jb-book
root: intro.md
parts:
  - caption: Worksheets
    numbered: 1
    chapters:
      - file: worksheets/worksheet1/worksheet1.md
        sections:
          - file: worksheets/worksheet1/py/student/worksheet1_py.ipynb
            title: my title that will not update
          - url: https://someexample.com
            title: my title that will update
```

title: Test for myst-init failing on master
body:
### Describe the problem

We have a test failing on master. It looks like it happens on the `jupyter_book.cli.main.init` function:

https://github.com/executablebooks/jupyter-book/runs/3776986362#step:6:51

Running the test locally, it looks like this is the `gist of the warning:

```
Passing a schema to Validator.iter_errors is deprecated and will be removed in a future release. Call validator.evolve(schema=new_schema).iter_errors(...) instead.')`
```

I think that this is a regression in the `jsonschema` package: https://python-jsonschema.readthedocs.io/en/stable/

Regression about `iter_errors` noted here: https://github.com/Julian/jsonschema/blob/main/CHANGELOG.rst#v400

title: Dependency conflict with voila 0.2.x
body:
### Describe the problem

I'd like to install both `jupyter-book` (0.11.3) and `voila` (0.2.15) into the same conda environment. Currently this results in a dependency conflict. 

Tracking down the source of the conflict is a little tricky as the error messages from either mamba or conda are a bit confusing. However, I *think* it is due to conflicting constraints on the `nbconvert` package. 

All versions of `voila` in the 0.2.x series require `nbconvert >=6.0.0,<7`.

Currently `jupyter-book` requires `myst-nb ~=0.12.0`. All versions of `myst-nb` in the 0.12.x series require `nbconvert >=5.5,<6`.

### Link to your repository or website

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

```bash
$ mamba create --name=test-jb-voila --dry-run --channel=conda-forge --override-channels --strict-channel-priority jupyter-book==0.11.3 voila==0.2.15
```

### The version of Python you're using

_No response_

0.11.3

_No response_

title: buidling book overwrites GH-pages custom domain setting
body:
### Describe the problem

I just set up a custom domain name for my book and followed github's instructions for using it (https://docs.github.com/en/pages/configuring-a-custom-domain-for-your-github-pages-site/managing-a-custom-domain-for-your-github-pages-site)

Specifically, along with configuration on the DNS provider's side, in the gh-pages repo you need to set the "custom domain" field in Settings/Pages to your vanity URL

After I set the custom domain, and save it, going to this domain works fine and I see my book. However, after I rebuild/republish my book, the "custom domain" box is empty and my custom URL now shows a 404 error. 

I did update the baseurl field in my _config.yml file (while retaining the repository url as my GH repo), but this doesn't solve the above problem.

title: Latest `thebe` loads CSS that breaks most paragraph CSS
body:
### Describe the problem

After updating [this jb site](http://vote.maxghenis.com) ([repo](https://github.com/MaxGhenis/vote/)) for the first time since January, the paragraph breaks and bold fonts stopped showing up. They render correctly when I build locally (using the latest jb). I serve it with GitHub Pages & Actions.

For example, here's how [this page](https://vote.maxghenis.com/nov2020/san-francisco.html#no-on-prop-f) looks locally and on the web:

## Locally
![Screenshot 2021-08-21 20 46 46](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6076111/130342697-3aec35f7-fdbe-4694-9fc9-ebbee0e04861.png)

## On the web
![Screenshot 2021-08-21 20 47 14](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6076111/130342714-fe2160b3-37b9-43f2-a9fc-81a2d74aeabf.png)

I've tried a few tweaks on the [workflow file](https://github.com/MaxGhenis/vote/blob/main/.github/workflows/deploy_jupyterbook.yml), which is essentially what's in the docs.

https://github.com/MaxGhenis/vote

title: Sphinx thebe is loading an outdated version of thebelab
body:
In the html files generated from the .md and .ipynb files an outdated index.js is called upon.

In the generated html files the following line:

`<script` async="async" `src="https://unpkg.com/thebelab@latest/lib/index.js"></script>`

should be replaced by 

`<script` async="async" `src="https://unpkg.com/thebe@latest/lib/index.js"></script>`

My kernel is not working if for mentioned fix is not applied.

I would be nice if this fix could be applied, so that it is not necessary to change this line in the generated html files manually.

Thanks in advance!

title: unwanted html links inserted
body:
**Describe the bug**

If a pattern resembling a URL occurs in the markdown of an ipynb file then it is tagged `<a class="reference external">` in the built html and appears as a broken link, despite no link being requested in the markdown syntax (i.e. no `[]()`). This affects things like filenames, presumably because of the presence of the `.` character.

Maybe this is a desired feature rather than a bug. But it seems like an undesirable one to have set by default. As far as I can find, it is also undocumented. A response to an old issue #1068 suggests that MyST markdown should not automatically hyperlink URLs.

Is this the work of the *linkify* myst extension? But the [documentation on sphinx configuration](https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/en/latest/sphinx/reference.html#sphinx-config-options) claims that this extension is not enabled by default. Or is it maybe the result of the default setting `myst_url_schemes: None`? In which case, what should this setting be in order to disable automatic recognition of URLs?

**To Reproduce**

- Clone this [minimal example repo](https://github.com/luketudge/jupyter-book-example).
- Run `jupyter-book build a_short_book`.
- View the file *a_short_book/_build/html/page1.html*.
- The phrase *program.py* is tagged as a link. (Though not *my_program.py*, the presence of an underscore seems to prevent it.)

**Expected behavior**

No html link should be inserted unless requested in the markdown. (Or failing that, the documentation should warn about this behavior).

**Environment**

- Python Version: 3.8.10
- Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`:
  - Jupyter Book: 0.11.1
  - External ToC: 0.2.2
  - MyST-Parser: 0.13.7
  - MyST-NB: 0.12.3
  - Sphinx Book Theme: 0.1.0
  - Jupyter-Cache: 0.4.2
  - NbClient: 0.5.3
- Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04.2

title: TOC documentation hasn't been updated from old TOC infrastructure
body:
[Docs suggest](https://github.com/executablebooks/jupyter-book/blob/b3019dc36c54a49f71066cf74c4b079d1c6bf500/docs/start/overview.md#table-of-contents-_tocym) that toc creation using the helper function is called as  `jupyter-book toc mybookname/` but that no longer works.

(The advice is also in a sidebar/margin which is __really easy to miss__. Putting it inside an admonition would be easier for folk wanting a quick start.)

The current invocation seems to take the form: `jupyter-book toc from-project mybookname/`

The docs example is also open as to what files are in the project directory, but the toc creator [`executablebooks/sphinx-external-toc/tools.py`](https://github.com/executablebooks/sphinx-external-toc/blob/main/sphinx_external_toc/tools.py) seems to require the presence of an `index.md` or `index.rst` file by default:

```
  -i, --index TEXT                File name (without suffix) considered as
                                  the index file in a folder  [default:
                                  index]
```

*Ah, actually, it seems that a root is automatically generated somehow? First dictionary sorted file maybe?*

Out of the can, the toc generator also seems to ignore `.ipynb` files?

```
 -e, --extension TEXT            File extensions to consider as documents
                                  (use multiple times)  [default: .rst, .md]
```

*The `-e` multiple times could be clarified by example: `(use multiple times, with or without the . eg -e ipynb -e .md)`*

For someone new to Jupyter Book with a set of arbitrary (`.ipynb`) notebooks in one or more directories, there is no immediate quickstart without having to check the help files to see why no toc file appears to be being generated.

When the toc command is run with appropriate settings, it seems to output to stdout rather than eg the expected default named toc file `_toc.yml`.

It's not clear to me if this should be addressed in Jupyter Book docs, and/or whether more aggressively opinionated default settings are required in https://github.com/executablebooks/sphinx-external-toc that stand a chance of "just working" (even to the extent of creating a default index file and warning/referring the user to it).

title: nbconvert pinned at <6
body:
Is there a reason why setup requires `nbconvert<6` https://github.com/executablebooks/jupyter-book/blob/0ecd3300494959a065ef226356203dfa6ec4927f/setup.cfg#L45 ?

Myst-nb is more generous (`nbconvert>=5.6,<7`); `nbconvert` has been at 6.x for a long time now.

title: File extensions no longer allowed for files with sections in the new ToC
body:
With the new ToC in  0.11, I noticed that file extensions can no longer be used for files that have sections under them. If I create a new book with `jupyter-book create mynewbook/` and change the  ToC to:

```yaml
format: jb-book
root: intro
chapters:
- file: markdown.md
  sections:
  - file: notebooks
```

I will get the error message `mynewbook/notebooks.ipynb: WARNING: document isn't included in any toctree`. Notably the file `markdown.md` is still in the book and works fine, but it no longer has the arrow and the child page under it. **Importantly** this is not picked up by the ToC converter, and it took me quite some time to figure out was wrong after using the ToC converter on an old project.

 It's useful to be able to distinguish files with the same name by specifying the extension, so it would be nice if this feature was available in 0.11, but if that is not possible I think it is important to change the ToC converter to  remove extensions from these sections. 

Notably, adding an extension on `notebooks` works fine while adding the extensions to the `into` file throws another error and halts the book build (`sphinx.errors.SphinxError: master file /home/joel/Downloads/mynewbook/intro.md.rst not found`).

**Environment**

- Python Version [e.g. 3.7.1]: `3.9.4`
- Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`:
  ```
  Jupyter Book      : 0.11.1
  External ToC      : 0.2.0
  MyST-Parser       : 0.13.7
  MyST-NB           : 0.12.3
  Sphinx Book Theme : 0.0.41
  Jupyter-Cache     : 0.4.2
  NbClient          : 0.5.3
  ```
- Operating System: `Ubuntu 20.10 5.11.0-7614-generic`

In #1283 we re-worked the documentation structure a bit. This seems to have introduced a bug where the `singlepage` PDF build via HTML now hangs indefinitely.

Build the book PDF via HTML with

```
tox -e docs-pdfhtml-update
```

this should hang indefinitely

title: Right hand TOC does not scroll

labels.name: :label: sphinx-book-theme
labels.description: An issue related to the theme

body:
**Describe the bug**

A few of our docs pages are quite long, and the right hand toc therefore, is also very long. I thought the right right toc would scroll (based on this https://github.com/executablebooks/jupyter-book/pull/176), but it doesn't in our jupyter-book. It goes off the page instead.
**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Go to https://docs.neuroml.org/Userdocs/Schemas/Channels.html
2. See right hand toc

Screenshot:

![neuroml-docs-jupyter-book-right-toc](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102575/109188597-fedcaf80-778a-11eb-8aa3-9513a087e7ed.png)


**Expected behavior**

The right hand toc should scroll. 

Our source repo is here: https://github.com/NeuroML/Documentation

**Environment**

- Python Version [e.g. 3.7.1]: 3.9.2
- Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`:
  ```
  $ jupyter-book --version

  Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.42
  MyST-Parser: 0.13.3
  Jupyter-Cache: 0.4.2
  NbClient: 0.5.1
  ```

Locally, I'm using https://github.com/choldgraf/sphinx-book-theme/tree/css6 branch for sphinx-book-theme (which fixes #1245)

- Operating System: Fedora Linux (release 33)

**Additional context**

N/A

title: Suppress warnings for non-consecutive header level increases
body:
**Describe the bug**

For some of my Jupyter Book pages, I'm outputting Markdown from code cells, and I'm using Markdown headers, which is triggering a `Non-consecutive header level increase; 0 to 3 [myst.header]` error on the page itself.

![Screen Shot 2021-04-13 at 12 34 16 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20325102/114589810-06cab300-9c56-11eb-993f-8c78b35158c8.png)

In the MyST Markdown documentation, I saw that you can[ suppress these warnings](https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/en/latest/using/howto.html?highlight=conf.py#suppress-warnings) in the config.py file, but I'm struggling to set up my _config.yml file in the right way for my Jupyter book.

This is what I have in my _config.yml file, which is not working:

![Screen Shot 2021-04-13 at 12 47 23 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20325102/114590167-66c15980-9c56-11eb-8e85-521f1efe1091.png)

Any suggestions would be much appreciated!

**Expected behavior**

Suppress warnings for non-consecutive header level increases

title: wrong histogram plot output - bernstein-vazirani-problem
body:
in the section bernstein-vazirani [bernstein-vazirani](https://qiskit.org/textbook/ch-algorithms/bernstein-vazirani.html) I tried to swap two lines of code, which effectively shouldn't change the output (and on my local machine, the output is indeed unchanged). 
but on-site (in Google Chrome browser) it swaps the output string from '011' to '110'
Changes as following:

**before:** (this is an exact copy of the code provided)
```
# initialization
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# importing Qiskit
from qiskit import IBMQ, Aer
from qiskit.providers.ibmq import least_busy
from qiskit import QuantumCircuit, ClassicalRegister, QuantumRegister, transpile, assemble

# import basic plot tools
from qiskit.visualization import plot_histogram

n = 3 # number of qubits used to represent s
s = '011'   # the hidden binary string

# We need a circuit with n qubits, plus one auxiliary qubit
# Also need n classical bits to write the output to
bv_circuit = QuantumCircuit(n+1, n)

# put auxiliary in state |->
bv_circuit.h(n)
bv_circuit.z(n)

# Apply Hadamard gates before querying the oracle
for i in range(n):
    bv_circuit.h(i)
    
# Apply barrier 
bv_circuit.barrier()

# Apply the inner-product oracle
s = s[::-1] # reverse s to fit qiskit's qubit ordering
for q in range(n):
    if s[q] == '0':
        bv_circuit.i(q)
    else:
        bv_circuit.cx(q, n)
        
# Apply barrier 
bv_circuit.barrier()

#Apply Hadamard gates after querying the oracle
for i in range(n):
    bv_circuit.h(i)

# Measurement
for i in range(n):
    bv_circuit.measure(i, i)

bv_circuit.draw()

# use local simulator
qasm_sim = Aer.get_backend('qasm_simulator')
shots = 1024
qobj = assemble(bv_circuit)
results = qasm_sim.run(qobj).result()
answer = results.get_counts()

plot_histogram(answer)
```


**after:**
```
# initialization
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# importing Qiskit
from qiskit import IBMQ, Aer
from qiskit.providers.ibmq import least_busy
from qiskit import QuantumCircuit, ClassicalRegister, QuantumRegister, transpile, assemble

# import basic plot tools
from qiskit.visualization import plot_histogram

n = 3 # number of qubits used to represent s
s = '011'   # the hidden binary string

# We need a circuit with n qubits, plus one auxiliary qubit
# Also need n classical bits to write the output to
bv_circuit = QuantumCircuit(n+1, n)

# put auxiliary in state |->
```
**# the following two lines have been exchanged**
```
bv_circuit.x(n)
bv_circuit.h(n)

# Apply Hadamard gates before querying the oracle
for i in range(n):
    bv_circuit.h(i)
    
# Apply barrier 
bv_circuit.barrier()

# Apply the inner-product oracle
s = s[::-1] # reverse s to fit qiskit's qubit ordering
for q in range(n):
    if s[q] == '0':
        bv_circuit.i(q)
    else:
        bv_circuit.cx(q, n)
        
# Apply barrier 
bv_circuit.barrier()

#Apply Hadamard gates after querying the oracle
for i in range(n):
    bv_circuit.h(i)

# Measurement
for i in range(n):
    bv_circuit.measure(i, i)

bv_circuit.draw()

# use local simulator
qasm_sim = Aer.get_backend('qasm_simulator')
shots = 1024
qobj = assemble(bv_circuit)
results = qasm_sim.run(qobj).result()
answer = results.get_counts()

plot_histogram(answer)
```

the expected Output is in both cases the bitstring 011

in earlier chapters we saw, that 
HZH = X
-> HZHH = XH
-> HZ = XH

therefore we don't expect any changes on the output.

I ran the program in my browser (Chrome) and the output of plot_histogram(answer) is in the first case correct: '011'
in the second case wrong: '110'

My system is Win10, in case this is effecting the browsers output.

the standard circuit:
![standard](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/72810349/114354846-128f7a00-9b6f-11eb-8f50-c443750c45c4.PNG)
![correct](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/72810349/114354843-11f6e380-9b6f-11eb-87d1-7abf5e6630b9.PNG)

the changed circuit:
![variation](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/72810349/114354848-13281080-9b6f-11eb-87bf-79d51165c1da.PNG)
![wrong](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/72810349/114354850-13281080-9b6f-11eb-95b9-8cdf1d2b73f8.PNG)

title: TOC behavior change after docutils jumps from 0.16 to 0.17
body:
My jupyter-book [repo is here](https://github.com/LeDataSciFi/ledatascifi-2021) and the [published site is here](ledatascifi.github.io/). The TOC uses parts, with subpages that dropdown when clicked. For example, one section is ```html

Schedule, tips, resources

``` which is produced by _toc.yml by ``` - part: Schedule, tips, resources chapters: - file: content/about/schedule title: "Dashboard, key links, schedule" ``` The update of docutils from 0.16 to 0.17 removed the `class="caption collapsible-parent"` from this, and made book navigation very hard. Reverting this by setting `docutils==0.16` inside requirements.txt restored the expected behavior.

title: Unable to use inline code block within a margin title?
body: **Describe the bug** Hi all! First, thank you so much for your hard work here. Jupyter Book has been an absolute delight to work with! I recently noticed that Jupyter Book doesn't seem to properly render margins that have an inline title. For example, in a notebook file I tried: ```` So, 2 + 2 = 4 ```{margin} Why not `2 + 2 = 5`? Well, because. ``` Great! ```` And the margin doesn't properly render until I remove the inline code block `2 + 2 = 5` from the margin title. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior: 1. Create a new markdown or notebook file `dummy.[md|ipynb]` with the above contents within, then build the book. 2. Notice that the margin doesn't render, but instead the Markdown gets rendered as-is. Here's a picture of what it looks like: **Expected behavior** I'd like to be able to use inline code blocks within the titles of a margin section :) **Environment** - Python Version [e.g. 3.7.1]: 3.7.8 - Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`: ``` Jupyter Book: 0.10.1 MyST-NB: 0.12.0 Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.41 MyST-Parser: 0.13.5 Jupyter-Cache: 0.4.2 NbClient: 0.5.3 ``` - Operating System: macOS **Additional context** I've checked the docs on [layout](https://jupyterbook.org/content/layout.html) and the [cheatsheet](https://jupyterbook.org/reference/cheatsheet.html), as well as the repo's current and former issues mentioning `code` and `margin`, but wasn't able to find a solution. Apologies if the solution is obvious!

title: The "raises-exception" tag is ignored in notebooks evaluated from Jupytext, errors logged intermittently.

labels.name: state: upstream
labels.description: Requires a change to a dependant package

body:
**Describe the bug**

I used to use this syntax in my Jupytext:

    ```{code-cell} ipython3
    :tags: [raises-exception]
    
    example of bad code
    ```

and it would (correctly) include the error messages in my documentation generated by

```bash
jupyter-book build docs-src
```

with cells after the tagged one evaluated. However, it is now the case that evaluation stops at the cell that raises an exception, and _sometimes_ (about 25% of the time) a subsequent cell raises an error in the log (`docs-src/_build/html/reports/MY-NOTEBOOK-NAME.log`) such as

```
NameError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-16-a60f71c96a9e> in <module>
      1 # The Awkward Array that it came from is not changed in this case.
----> 2 ak_array1

NameError: name 'ak_array1' is not defined
NameError: name 'ak_array1' is not defined
```

because (in this example) the variable `ak_array1` gets defined in one of those cells that wasn't evaluated. My best guess is that the exception stops evaluation at one point, but evaluation starts again many cells later, and it doesn't work because those cells relied upon the cells that were skipped. In some cases, it's not a NameError, but an old value of a variable is used that should have been replaced by a reassignment.

The cell where evaluation begins again, if at all, is random: I made trivial changes to my file and kept running `jupyter-book` to force reevaluation dozens of times.

**Environment**

- Python Version:

```
Python 3.8.8 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Feb 20 2021, 16:22:27)
[GCC 9.3.0] on linux`
```

- Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`:

```
Jupyter Book: 0.10.0
MyST-NB: 0.11.1
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.39
MyST-Parser: 0.13.5
Jupyter-Cache: 0.4.2
NbClient: 0.5.2
```

- Operating System:

```
Linux zprime 5.8.0-7642-generic #47~1612288990~20.04~b8113e7-Ubuntu SMP Wed Feb 3 02:25:36 UTC 2 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

This does seem to be JupyterBook version dependent (though I can't say which of JupyterBook's dependencies, if not JupyterBook itself). I first caught it in CI, then upgraded all my conda and pip packages (JupyterBook is one of my few pip packages) to be able to reproduce it. With my old set of versions, I couldn't reproduce it locally.

**Additional context**

I wasn't able to find much else on the "raises-exception" tag. It used to be my favorite tag, but I don't see many people talking about it/using it. Could it be under-tested?

(In documentation, I think that showing examples of errors is as important as showing code that works.)

title: Flat _toc.yml results in unexpected book structure with pdflatex builder
body:
**Describe the bug**

I'm not sure this is a bug or I'm just not understanding [the docs correctly](https://jupyterbook.org/customize/toc.html#how-headers-and-sections-map-onto-to-book-structure). When building the pdf of a book with the `pdflatex` builder and a flat _toc layout (i.e. only `- file` entries, no parts or sections and no nesting), all documents are included as subsections of the first document, regardless of structure of the headings within the files. This behavior seems specific to the `pdflatex` builder, as the `html` output seems as expected.

**To Reproduce**

I've set up an example jb project to illustrate the behavior: https://github.com/rossbar/toc_test_book

The `_toc.yml` is structured [like so](https://github.com/rossbar/toc_test_book/blob/master/_toc.yml)

To setup:

```
git clone https://github.com/rossbar/toc_test_book
cd toc_test_book
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

The html document is organized as expected (three top-level documents corresponding to the preface, ch1 and ch2):

```
jb build .
```

The output with the pdflatex builder has one top-level doc (the preface) with the subsections of the preface being treated as chapters, and the ch1 and ch2 documents being treated as subsubsections of the last section in the preface.

```
jb build . --builder pdflatex
```

**Expected behavior**

Again - not sure if this is a bug or I'm not reading the docs correctly. I would've expected the pdflatex doc structure to match that of the html document. If the current behavior **is** expected, then perhaps adding the flat _toc structure as an example in [this section in the docs](https://jupyterbook.org/customize/toc.html#how-headers-and-sections-map-onto-to-book-structure) and explaining the mapping from the `_toc.yml` to the output pdf structure would be helpful.

**Environment**

- Python Version [e.g. 3.7.1]: 3.9.1
- Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`: 
   * Jupyter Book: 0.9.1
   * MyST-NB: 0.10.2
   * Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.39
   * MyST-Parser: 0.12.10
   * Jupyter-Cache: 0.4.2
   * NbClient: 0.5.1
- Operating System: Linux

**Additional context**

I've also tried with the `jupyterbook-latex` sphinx extension, but this had no effect the output pdf document structure.

title: Google Analytics Seems To Be Broken For A Certain Use Case

html:

**Environment**

title: in `_check_toc_entries`, `sections` is assumed to be a dict but  a string was passed
body:
**Describe the bug**

Unfortunately this is in the middle of a repo I'm changing a lot and I can't push the changes that cause this up yet, sorry about that. Below is the info I best have and I hope it's sufficient to understand the issue, if not I'll try to clean up my example so it's reproducible, but perhaps this is enough to point in the right direction...

Using j-book 0.9.1 on a Mac (python 3.8), with the following `_toc.yml` file:

```
# Table of contents
# Learn more at https://jupyterbook.org/customize/toc.html

# First entry here is the website/book's landing page.
- file: overview

# The rest is structured in *parts* that then have chapters/sections.

- part: Overview
  chapters:

- part: Syllabus

-rw-r--r--  1 fperez  10983 Jan 16 16:15 syllabus.md
```

Again, sorry for the partial report!! LMK if it's not enough and I'll work on a cleaner one :)

title: No outputs are shown with nbformat 5.1 and .py notebooks
body:
**Describe the bug**

Because of random id addition in nbformat 5.1 https://github.com/jupyter/nbformat/pull/205 it seems like the notebook ran fine but the outputs can not be found in `jupyter-cache`

Note that outputs are shown when reverting `nbformat` with `pip install nbformat==5.0.8`

This results in blank outputs (as if the notebook was not run):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1680079/104743192-b1146680-574b-11eb-8503-25138667c224.png)

and some warnings like:
```
WARNING: Couldn't find cache key for notebook file python_scripts/02_numerical_pipeline_introduction.py. Outputs will not be inserted.
WARNING: Notebook code has no file extension metadata, defaulting to `.txt`
```

At the root of this there is the fact that `jupytext.read` creates a different notebook from the `.py` file with different random ids.

This problem was seen in a different context in Jupytext here: https://github.com/mwouts/jupytext/issues/715 and reverting nbformat to 5.0.8 was done in jupytext setup.py. cc @mwouts.

I am not sure where the right place for a possible fix is:
- nbformat or maybe jupytext should try to produce stable cell ids?
- jupytext-cache should still reuse the outputs cache if cell ids differ ? My understanding is that there is a similar mechanism for markdown cells.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

```sh
git clone https://github.com/lesteve/scikit-learn-mooc --branch nbformat-5.1-regression --depth 1
cd scikit-learn-mooc/jupyter-book
conda create -n test-jupyter-book python -y
conda activate test-jupyter-book
pip install -r ../requirements.txt
pip install jupyter-book
rm -rf _build/ && jb build .
```

Open the generate HTML in your favorite browser (firefox in my case):
```sh
firefox _build/html/python_scripts/02_numerical_pipeline_introduction.html
```


**Expected behavior**

Ouptuts should be shown:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1680079/104743550-1c5e3880-574c-11eb-8c3a-d3f98bc6c082.png)


**Environment**

<details>

```

title: Cannot find master file when only_build_toc_files is enabled
body:
**Describe the bug**

I'd like to use the new `only_build_toc_files` setting which looks like a good feature, however it is not working as I expected.

**To Reproduce**

My original `_config.yml` file looks like
```
exclude_patterns: [
    # a bunch of glob patterns here
]
only_build_toc_files: false # TODO: enable this setting 

execute:
    execute_notebooks: off

sphinx:
    config:
        suppress_warnings: misc.highlighting_failure
        mathjax_path: https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js
```

When I change `only_build_toc_files` to `true` I get an error `sphinx.errors.SphinxError: master file /Users/paddy/git_repos/course_mlbd/index.md not found` but that file `index.md` is there and is in my `_toc.yml` as `- file: index.md`.

**Expected behavior**

My understanding is this new config just determines what is built which should be only the file specified in `_toc.yml`. Just to check that to stop executing a notebook it would still need to be in `exclude_patterns`?

**Environment**

- Python Version [e.g. 3.7.1]: `3.8.5`
- Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`: `0.9.1`
- Operating System: macOS

title: Using myst_parser's new "substitutions" feature
body:
**Describe the bug**

I'm trying to get the new "substitution" directive from [myst_parser v0.13](https://github.com/executablebooks/MyST-Parser/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md) and running into some trouble translating the "conf.py" file to jupyterbook's "_config.yml".

### Problem 1: dependency issues

Trying to upgrade `myst_parser` to v0.13 caused some issues with dependencies for `myst-nb`
```
ERROR: pip's dependency resolver does not currently take into account all the packages that are installed. This behaviour is the source of the following dependency conflicts.
myst-nb 0.10.1 requires myst-parser~=0.12.9, but you have myst-parser 0.13.0 which is incompatible.
jupytext 1.6.0 requires markdown-it-py~=0.5.2; python_version >= "3.6", but you have markdown-it-py 0.6.0 which is incompatible.
```

I think this was just a warning, and I ended up upgrading myst_parser anyway. 

### Problem 2: `myst_enable_extensions`

The [Myst docs](https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/en/latest/using/syntax-optional.html?highlight=substitution#substitutions-with-jinja2) say:

> To enable all the syntaxes explained below:
```
myst_enable_extensions = [
    "amsmath",
    "colon_fence",
    "deflist",
    "dollarmath",
    "html_image",
    "linkify",
    "replacements",
    "smartquotes",
    "substitution"
]
```

What is the way to enable these in jupyterbook? Here is my attempt in `_config.yml`:

```
# bunch of stuff that's not relevant here

sphinx:
  config:
    html_show_copyright: false
    html_extra_path: ['files']

parse:
  myst_extended_syntax: true

myst_enable_extensions: 
  - amsmath
  - colon_fence
  - deflist
  - dollarmath
  - html_image
  - linkify
  - replacements
  - smartquotes
  - substitution

myst_substitutions:
  course: 'THISISAMAZING1010'
```

### Problem 3: Using substitutions

I imagine that with the `_config.yml` file above, this should work in any md file:

```This is the official syllabus and course outline for COSC 123 {{ course }}.```

... but {{ course }} doesn't replace the text as I expected. 

I also tried to add the substitution definition at the top of the file as "front-matter" using three dashes, but that doesn't work either (no error, just leaves it as {{ varname }}. 

E.g., 

```
---
substitutions:
  course2: "I'm a substitution"
---
```

**To Reproduce**

See above.

**Expected behavior**

title: Dropdown admonition doesn't render
body:
I copied the instructions to create a [dropdown admonition](https://jupyterbook.org/content/content-blocks.html#dropdown-admonitions), and while the first `{note}` one works, the `{admonition,dropdown,tip}` one doesn't: the `:::` syntax isn't rendered, while the `` syntax just doesn't show up.

Here's what I put into a markdown cell in my ipynb:
````
```{note}
:class: dropdown
The note body will be hidden!
```

:::{admonition,dropdown,tip} Click here!
Here's what's inside!
:::

```{admonition,dropdown,tip} Click here!
Here's what's inside!
```
````
And here's what showed up:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6076111/103119739-80984b80-4629-11eb-9821-2a2b373bf6bc.png)

MyST-NB: 0.10.1
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.39
MyST-Parser: 0.13.0

title: Scrollbar occluded for dragging by page ToC
body:
**Describe the bug**

I think the in-page ToC is placed above of the scrollbar, making it impossible to select it for scrolling next to the ToC.

![scrollbar-hidden-behind-the-on-this-page-toc](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3837114/101392755-68ed6300-38c6-11eb-81ef-3026ea162eea.gif)

**To Reproduce**
I noticed it on a published jupyter-book that I had no part in deploying. On this page, it may be reproducible: https://earth-env-data-science.github.io/lectures/environment/python_environments.html

Go to the link, try using the scroll bar behind the page ToC and when it isnt behind the page ToC.

**Expected behavior**

To be able to click on the scrollbar independently on if the page ToC is next to it.

**Environment**

I think jupyter-book 0.5.2 is used based on [this code](https://github.com/earth-env-data-science/earth-env-data-science-book/blob/a97d6c569e7be0ded0d58ce55a34276dbe8bbe91/.circleci/config.yml#L95-L97), so perhaps it is no longer an isssue.

title: Thank you!
body: Just wanted to say thanks for your help, and I didn't know where else to do it.

title: Possible bug with Chapter references

labels.name: :label: toc
labels.description: An issue related to the toc structure

body:
**Describe the bug**
When I use ``` {ref}`my-reference` ``` or ```{numref}`my-reference` ``` for Chapters headings that are at the start of a markdown file, the link doesn't render.

**To Reproduce**
Sorry, I can't share the book repo at the moment, but this is what it looks like. 
Chapter markdown looks like this:
```
(my-reference)=
## Title of Chapter 2
text text text

(subsection-reference)=
### Subsection here
text text text

```

The following renders incorrectly:
```
{numref}`my-reference`
[]`my-reference`
```
The following renders fine:
```
{ref}`Chapter 2<my-reference>`
{numref}`subsection-reference`
```

**Expected behavior**
I thought that the "normal" reference would work. If it's not meant to, maybe that could be added to the documentation?

**Environment**

- Python: 3.7.2
- ouput of `jupyter-book --version`:
```
Jupyter Book: 0.8.3
MyST-NB: 0.10.1
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.39
MyST-Parser: 0.12.9
Jupyter-Cache: 0.4.1
NbClient: 0.4.1
``` 
- Operating System: MacOS High Sierra v10.13.6

title: NotImplementedError when building book on Windows
body:
**Describe the bug**

On Windows, Python 3.8 and 3.9, calling `jupyter-book build` fails with a `NotImplementedError` error coming from `asyncio\events.py`.

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. jupyter create testbook
2. rm testbook/*.md
3. cp testbook/notebooks.ipynb testbook/notebooks2.ipynb
4. Modify _toc.yml: 
```
- file: notebooks
- file: notebooks2
```
5. convert notebooks to python files and get rid of the notebooks
```
cd testbook
jupytext notebooks.ipynb --to py:percent
jupytext notebooks2.ipynb --to py:percent
rm *.ipynb
```
6. Modify the _config.py, append at the end:
```
sphinx:
  config:
    nb_custom_formats:
        .py:
            - jupytext.reads
            - fmt: py
```
7. jupyter-book build testbook
8. Error arises

As mentioned if only one of the notebooks is converted to .py then it works.

**Expected behavior**

 I would expect the book to build without errors.

**Environment**

- Python Version [e.g. 3.7.1]: 3.8.6
- Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`:

MyST-Parser: 0.12.10
Jupyter-Cache: 0.4.1
NbClient: 0.5.1
- Operating System: Ubuntu 18.04.5

Additional information/Context:

I prefer to work on python scripts rather than on jupyter notebooks so that I can use an IDE like VSCode. 
Typically for the first page of the book (equivalent to intro.md), I already need to do some calculations to show things like
what is the current version of the stuff I am running, or grab some information from the environment etc, therefore I would like that first page is a python script too rather than a markdown file.

title: "prev-next-bottom" improper display.

labels.name: :label: sphinx-book-theme
labels.description: An issue related to the theme

body:
**Describe the bug**

The buttons at the bottom of each page for the next and the previous pages will sometimes get mushed to the left of the page and clip into the page footer.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. For some page in the book, make the title of the next page so long that it wraps inside the next page button.
2. Make the title of the previous page short so it won't wrap.
3. See how, for the current page, the buttons lose some styles and aren't properly aligned.

Notice how this also happens if the previous button wraps its text but the next doesn't

**Expected behavior**

Despite either the previous page or next page buttons wrapping their text, the buttons should display with their respective anchor styles and not clip into the page footer.

[Repo](https://github.com/copa-uniandes/optimizacion).

**Example**

Improper:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28278569/99201677-36928f00-277a-11eb-9723-03a44e591808.png)

Proper:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28278569/99201694-43af7e00-277a-11eb-913e-7cb3722d183a.png)


**Environment**

Github-Workflow ubuntu-latest environment.

- Python Version: 3.7
- Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`: 
````
Jupyter Book: 0.8.3
MyST-NB: 0.10.1
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.38
MyST-Parser: 0.12.10
Jupyter-Cache: 0.4.1
NbClient: 0.5.1
````
- Operating System: Ubuntu-latest, though this also happens when building on Windows 10.

**Additional context**

I doubt this is a Sphinx issue. Rather, I'll look into the jupyter book theme and see what can be done to fix this.

title: Fail to build pdf with pdflatex when notebook is in a subdirectory
body:
**Describe the bug**

Given the template project, when "notebooks.ipynb" is moved to a subdirectory and _toc updated accordingly, the PDF failed to build due to the output image being not found by Latex.

Latex error message:  

```
'LaTeX Warning: File `{_build/jupyter_execute/notebooks_2_0}.png' not found on input line 385.'
```

Note that the output image is properly generated by the notebook, but in the proper sub-directory: `_build/jupyter_execute/examples/notebooks_2_0.png`

Building the HTML works as expected.


**To Reproduce**

* Start from the basic example `jupyter-book create mynewbook/`
* Move the 
`notebooks.ipynb` into a subdirectory: 

```
cd mynewbook; mkdir examples; move notebooks.ipynb examples
```

* Adjust _toc accordingly:

```
- file: content
  sections:
    - file: markdown
    - file: examples/notebooks
```

* `jb build --builder pdflatex newbook ` will trigger the error

**Expected behavior**

The image file path in the generate latex source files should mirror the execution structure such that the generated images are found, and the PDF should  be generated w/o errors.

title: Sphinx 3.3 causes a warning to pop up in our doc builds
body:
Starting with Sphinx 3.3, building single-page versions of the documentation (Latex or HTML PDF) results in a warning in our documentation builds:

https://github.com/executablebooks/jupyter-book/pull/1073/checks?check_run_id=1347710854#step:7:94

The error is something like:

```
/home/runner/work/jupyter-book/jupyter-book/docs/reference/cheatsheet.md:394: WARNING: no number is assigned for table: example-table
```

I'm not sure why this popped up all of a sudden, maybe @najuzilu or @mmcky ran into this before?

title: Chapter's md file requires a subsection to work properly.
body:
**Describe the bug**

Is there a reason why the introductory MD file for the chapter has to have a subsection? Let me explain: the example from the [official documentation](https://jupyterbook.org/customize/toc.html#how-headers-and-sections-map-onto-to-book-structure) shows the following:

This is the **chapter1.md**

```markdown
# Chapter 1 title

Lorem ipsum ...

## Chapter 1 second header

Lorem ipsum ...
```

**chapter1section.md** is:

```markdown
# Chapter 1 section title

Lorem ipsum ...

## Chapter 1 section second header

Lorem ipsum ...
```

Then **Chapter 1 section title** will be treated in the final document (HTML) as a level three header (###), but if you remove **## Chapter 1 section header** (chapter1section.md stays the same) I would expect that **# Chapter 1 section title** would be treated as a level two header but that does not happen. Is that a 

**To Reproduce**

Create a Jupyter Book with the following _toc.yml:

```yaml
- file: content/intro
  numbered: true

- part: Part 1
  chapters:
    - file: content/part1/ch1/ch1.md
      expand_sections: true
      sections:
        - file: content/part1/ch1/ch1section.md
```
md files have the same content as described above except **ch1.md**:

```markdown
# Chapter 1 title

Lorem ipsum ...
```

Notice that there are no subsections here.

**Expected behavior**

I would expect that **# Chapter 1 section title** would be treated as a level two heading when no subsections are present
in **ch1.md**, but that does not happen.

**A link to your documentation repository.**

Not required.

**If relevant, a minimal example of the input text should be supplied,
together with a screen-shot of the output document and/or command-line output, e.g.**

Not required.

**Environment**

Python verison: Python 3.8.3
`jupyter-book --version`
Jupyter Book: 0.8.3
MyST-NB: 0.10.1
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.38
MyST-Parser: 0.12.10
Jupyter-Cache: 0.4.1
NbClient: 0.5.1

- Operating System: Arch Linux

**Additional context**

None.

title: Building launch links for binderhub and jupyterhub
body:
**Describe the bug**

Issues #832, #746, #494 deal with 404 not found errors, but I could not find a clear solution _new to Jupyter-book so it may be my fault_. I am facing two issues that when I build a jupyter-book and add a binderhub_url and jupyterhub_url, both lead to a __404 not found error__, then the github-pages keeps failing. 

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. use `jupyter-book create dynamics` 
2. add launch buttons to the `_config.yml` <- `binderhub_url: https://mybinder.org` and `jupyterhub_url: https://ugmelab.uconn.edu` _this needs a github.uconn.edu to access, but binderhub produces same bug. 
3. create engineering-dynamics repo on github.com and push files to repository url
4. use `jupyter-book build .` in dynamics -> HTML pages are in _build/html
5. Navigate to any `*.ipynb` file, click the Launch button (Binder)
6. receive 404 file not found error

**Expected behavior**

I'm not sure how to get the ipynb files to show up in binder or my own jupyterhub. 

A link to your documentation repository:
https://github.com/cooperrc/engineering-dynamics

```console
$ jupyter-book build .
no errors :)
```
__Error comes from launching a notebook from the `_build` and the gh-pages won't show the book.__

body:

jovyan@8367569ee062:~$ mkdir test\ book

file: '1'
sections:
