title: Multiple Chapters per Part
body:
I'm trying to create a jupyterbook with parts, chapters and sections. It looks like there is a maximum of one chapter per part, is that true? 

**To Reproduce**

My _toc.yml file looks like this:

```
- file: intro

- part: The first part
  chapters:
  - file: first_chapter
    sections:
      - file: first_section
  chapters:
  - file: second_chapter
    sections:
      - file: second_section
```

**Expected behavior**

I would expect both chapters and both sections to be visible in the document. However, only the second part is included

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12532091/95765141-b5933400-0cb1-11eb-8481-ebc5abc18e68.png)

I've added all the code here to reproduce: https://github.com/ratnanil/jb_multiple_chapters

**Environment**

- Python Version: 3.7.8
- Output of `jupyter-book --version`:
```
Jupyter Book: 0.8.0
MyST-NB: 0.10.0
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.36
MyST-Parser: 0.12.8
Jupyter-Cache: 0.4.1
NbClient: 0.5.0
```
- Operating System:

title: Full-width doesn't seem to work on Markdown cells
body:
I can't seem to get `full-width` to work on Markdown cells, be it in regular `.ipynb` notebooks or MyST-based notebooks with the `+++ {"tags": ["full-width"]}` syntax.

What seems to be happening is that the MyST `+++` syntax generates the correct `.ipynb` source (presumably via JupyText?), with Markdown content split into cells with properly applied tags, but when that gets converted into HTML, the cells are merged and the tag information gets lost. At least when inspecting the generated HTML, there's no `div` that would group the content between a pair of `+++` lines, to which the tags could be applied as classes.

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. `jb create test-book`
2. Edit `notebooks.ipynb`, adding `"tags": ["full-width"]` to the `metadata` field of the first Markdown cell.
3. `jb build test-book`
4. Open the book in the browser.

As per [the description of the `+++` feature in the docs](https://jupyterbook.org/file-types/myst-notebooks.html#markdown-content), I would expect the content in the page to be full-width, but it's not.

title: Incorrect header size rendering
body:
**Describe the bug**

When using markdown headers (`#`, `##`, `###`) the built html does not render them correctly. Concretely, `###` headers are rendered as larger than `##` headers.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Go to https://source-separation.github.io/tutorial/data/musdb18.html#downloading-and-inspecting-musdb18-clips
2. Notice how the header "Downloading and inspecting MUSDB18 clips" is much smaller than the one below it "Downloading MUSDB18 clips with nussl".
3. Look at the source to confirm the first header should be larger than the second: https://github.com/source-separation/tutorial/blob/master/book/data/musdb18.ipynb

**Expected behavior**

`##` headers should be rendered larger than `###` headers and be consistent with how they are rendered in the source Jupyter notebook.

**Environment**

- Python Version [e.g. 3.7.1]: 3.7.9
- Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`:
```
Jupyter Book: 0.8.2
MyST-NB: 0.10.1
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.37
MyST-Parser: 0.12.10
Jupyter-Cache: 0.4.1
NbClient: 0.5.0
```
- Operating System: macOS 10.14.6

**Additional context**

We still LOVE jupyter book, we've written a whole conference tutorial (book) with it!
https://source-separation.github.io/tutorial

title: R's print output needs improvement
body: ### Describe the bug Print outputs of R add weird characters to rendered book. Print outputs of R are needed in cases where Jupyter output of R objects is not yet well handled (e.g., nested data frames). ### Expected behavior #### What is should look like: ``` # A tibble: 142 x 5 # Groups: country, continent [142] country continent data mean_life_exp life_exp_ci 1 Afghanistan Asia 37.5 2 Albania Europe 68.4 3 Algeria Africa 59.0 4 Angola Africa 37.9 5 Argentina Americas 69.1 6 Australia Oceania 74.7 7 Austria Europe 73.1 8 Bahrain Asia 65.6 9 Bangladesh Asia 49.8 10 Belgium Europe 73.6 # … with 132 more rows ``` #### Screenshot of what it looks like: #### Source Jupyter notebook file code: - https://github.ubc.ca/MDS-2020-21/DSCI_523_r-prog_students/blob/master/lectures/lectures/07-mapping-and-nested-data-frames.ipynb #### Rendered book with output: - https://pages.github.ubc.ca/MDS-2020-21/DSCI_523_r-prog_students/lectures/07-mapping-and-nested-data-frames.html#nested-data-frames ### Reproduce: Here is my makefile for building the book: ``` book: cp README.md lectures/README.md jupyter-book build lectures cp -r lectures/_build/html/* docs ``` Then I run: ``` make book ``` and deploy it on the master branch (`docs` folder) using GitHub Pages. ### Environment - Python Version [e.g. 3.7.1]: Python 3.7.6 - Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`: ``` Jupyter Book: 0.7.4 MyST-NB: 0.8.3 Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.35 MyST-Parser: 0.8.2 Jupyter-Cache: 0.2.2 ``` - Operating System: Mac OS Catalina 10.15.6

title: Wide equations no lateral scrolling
body:
**Describe Bug**

When equations are too wide for fitting in a page AND the equation is in an admonition box, you cannot "move the window laterally" / "side scroll" to see the entire equation.

Example before scrolling:

![Screenshot 2020-09-22 at 17 39 33](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24327668/93905011-c5df7100-fcfa-11ea-9fcd-826b6c0815b9.png)

Example after scrolling:

![Screenshot 2020-09-22 at 17 40 09](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24327668/93905218-ff17e100-fcfa-11ea-8c30-7f5fd04a3e18.png)



**Expected behavior**

When equations are too wide for fitting in a page but they are not in an admonition box, you can still scroll on the side to see the entire equation. I would expect the same in the case of the admonition. For example you see that the equation above the yellow admonition in the previous screen shots can be shown by scrolling.

title: Standalone pages don't show Plotly figures
body:
**Describe the bug**

Since upgrading jupyter-book the figures produced by Plotly no longer appear when building standalone pages.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Create a jupyter notebook `mypage.ipynb` with a Plotly figure
2. Run `jb build path/to/mypage.ipynb`
3. View the resulting html file
4. See no figure

**Expected behavior**

Plotly figures worked with my previous version of jupyter-book, sorry I don't remember the version number but it used `jb page ...` rather than `jb build ...` for standalone pages.

**Environment**

- Python Version [e.g. 3.7.1]: 3.7.7
- Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`: 0.8.2
- Operating System: Windows 10

**Additional context**

I assume this is  because [jupyterbooks with Plotly content now need to load `require.js` in `_config.yml](https://jupyterbook.org/interactive/interactive.html#plotly), but I don't see how to do that with a standalone page.

title: jupyter-book mishandles filenames that have 2 periods in the name
body:
**Describe the bug**
When processing something like `python2.7-example.md` the build step will fail, reporting a failure to find `python2.md`

A clear and concise description of what the bug is.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Create a file with a name containing 2 "."s
2. jupyter-book build .


**Expected behavior**

It should pick the extension by finding the last "." in a filename.

**Environment**
```bash
jupyter-book --version
Jupyter Book: 0.8.1
MyST-NB: 0.10.1
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.36
MyST-Parser: 0.12.9
Jupyter-Cache: 0.4.1
NbClient: 0.5.0

python --version
Python 2.7.18
```
- Operating System: Linux

I have not tried it using 3.7 or 3.8, but I suspect that the python version is not relevant to this bug.

**Additional context**

None

title: Cannot make an external URL the first item in the TOC

labels.name: :label: toc
labels.description: An issue related to the toc structure

body:
**Describe the bug**

When [changing](https://github.com/UBICenter/childallowance/pull/48/commits/afe42af7daa6ddc8a8527cddf0bff47d0cf7bc52) `_toc.yml` to make an external URL the first item:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6076111/92416209-4bff9300-f111-11ea-9e45-b55b405034a6.png)

I get [this error](https://github.com/UBICenter/childallowance/pull/48/checks?check_run_id=1083096779#step:4:23):

>Extension error:
Handler <function add_toc_to_sphinx at 0x7f1d88fa7550> for event 'config-inited' threw an exception (exception: 'file')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/share/miniconda/envs/childallowance/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sphinx/events.py", line 110, in emit
    results.append(listener.handler(self.app, *args))
  File "/usr/share/miniconda/envs/childallowance/lib/python3.8/site-packages/jupyter_book/toc.py", line 192, in add_toc_to_sphinx
    app.config["master_doc"] = _posix_no_suffix(toc["file"])
KeyError: 'file'

**Environment**

- Python Version [e.g. 3.7.1]: 3.8
- Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`: 0.8.0
- Operating System: Ubuntu

**Additional context**
This wasn't an issue prior to 0.8.0, as the TOC didn't display the first item:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6076111/92416320-c0d2cd00-f111-11ea-88d5-7eb4c4f4adb9.png)

But in 0.8.0, that external link is no longer the topmost link, as I'd like:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6076111/92416311-b7496500-f111-11ea-910b-608b8bafef5c.png)

title: Intertactive outputs not showing in v0.8.0 (plotly)
body:
**Describe the bug**

A jb page built from an ipynb file shows Plotly outputs in version 0.7.5, but not 0.8.0.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Execute [this `index.ipynb` file](https://github.com/UBICenter/childallowance/blob/8dfeb91e0c8801c2b70dcb483e41105f05648bdc/jb/index.ipynb), which shows two `plotly` plots, with `jb 0.8.0`.
2. View the result, which doesn't show the `plotly` output.

**Expected behavior**

The `plotly` outputs should be visible. When I pin `jupyter-book==0.7.5`, it works, as visible [here](http://childallowance.ubicenter.org). The GitHub Actions execution log looks essentially the same with [0.7.5](https://github.com/UBICenter/childallowance/runs/1076714670?check_suite_focus=true#step:4:14) vs [0.8.0](https://github.com/UBICenter/childallowance/runs/1070600046?check_suite_focus=true#step:4:27).

A link to your documentation repository: https://github.com/UBICenter/childallowance/

**Environment**

- Python Version [e.g. 3.7.1]: 3.7.7
- Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`: 0.7.5 and 0.8.0 (via environment in GitHub Actions)
- Operating System: ubuntu

title: TOC / navigation sidebar reopens when moving to another page
body:
**Describe the bug**

When the TOC is closed, moving forward or backward to another page loads that page with the TOC open.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Open any page.
2. Click on the arrow in the top-left to close the TOC side-bar.
3. Click on the "previous page" or "next page" navigation links at the bottom of the current page.
4. The new page will load, with the TOC side-bar reopened.

**Expected behavior**

The TOC side-bar status (open vs. closed) persists when moving between sequential pages.

A link to your documentation repository.
see e.g. https://jupyterbook.org/file-types/index.html

title: Overriding configuration settings changes sibling defaults
body:
**Describe the bug**

Setting custom `html` configuration values overrides default value used for `home_page_in_navbar`.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Run
```
jb create testbook
jb build testbook
```

(If you open the built book, notice the nav bar contains the introduction page, [as per the docs default config](https://jupyterbook.org/customize/config.html#configuration-reference))

Edit `testbook/_config.yml` to contain, for example:

```yaml
# Book settings
title: My sample book
author: The Jupyter Book Community
logo: logo.png

latex:
  latex_documents:
    targetname: book.tex

html:
  extra_footer: ""
```

and run `jb build testbook`.

**Expected behavior**

Opening the built book, I would expect the introduction page to still be displayed on the nav bar. It feels like this could be easily fixed by providing the appropriate default value [in this line](https://github.com/executablebooks/jupyter-book/blob/master/jupyter_book/yaml.py#L47) but [a comment on top of the file](https://github.com/executablebooks/jupyter-book/blob/master/jupyter_book/yaml.py#L8) makes it look like this is the desired behaviour, which imo is a _weird_ default behaviour.

Alternatively (and probably better?) would be to merge recursively the default configuration with the user configuration at the end of the `yaml_to_sphinx` function.

I can fix this easily, I just need someone to confirm I can change this.

**Environment**

- Python Version 3.7.6
- Package versions or output of `jupyter-book --version`:
```
jb --version
Jupyter Book: 0.7.5
MyST-NB: 0.8.5
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.35
MyST-Parser: 0.9.1
Jupyter-Cache: 0.3.0
```
- Operating System: Windows

title: Syntax highlighting for non-python kernels in code-cell directive
body:
Consider the following `.md` file

````markdown
---
jupytext:
  formats: md:myst
  text_representation:
    extension: .md
    format_name: myst
    format_version: '0.8'
    jupytext_version: 1.4.1+dev
kernelspec:
  display_name: Coconut
  language: coconut
  name: coconut
---

```{code-cell} coconut
range(10) |> map$(pow$(?, 2)) |> list
```
````

Changing the kernel to [`coconut`](http://coconut-lang.org/) works, as can be seen in the rendered image below.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17755465/90306039-802fbd00-de9f-11ea-93b7-f16c26465d77.png)


But the syntax highlighting does not. Is it possible to somehow define a syntax file for different kernels?

title: Build fails with Scala kernel notebooks

labels.name: :label: pdflatex
labels.description: Issues specific to building PDFs via latex

body:
When building books  with Almond notebooks (https://almond.sh/), jupyter-book fails to render the cells' output.

In Jupyter Notebook,  the output of a cell is rendered in color:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7091705/90206649-9748af00-ddba-11ea-951e-704d59f8865b.png)

This is rendered like this by the HTML builder:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7091705/90206775-e858a300-ddba-11ea-87e0-b6cfc8ed53d5.png)

The pdflatex builder fails completely.

```

! Package inputenc Error: Unicode character ^^[ (U+001B)
(inputenc)                not set up for use with LaTeX.

See the inputenc package documentation for explanation.
Type  H <return>  for immediate help.
 ...                                              
                                                  
l.344 ...[39m: ^^[[32mInt^^[[39m = ^^[[32m1^^[[39m
                                                  
? 

```

There seems to be a problem with the ANSI escape codes used for color.


**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Install the Scala kernel (Almond)
2. Create a book
3. Add a scala notebook
4. Add a cell that produces output
5. Build the book

**Expected behavior**

The book renders the notebook like Jupyter Notebook.

Here is an example of notebook that produces the problem:

```
{
 "cells": [
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "# Scala Notebook"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 4,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "text/plain": [
       "\u001b[36mres3\u001b[39m: \u001b[32mInt\u001b[39m = \u001b[32m1\u001b[39m"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 4,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "1"
   ]
  }
 ],
 "metadata": {
  "kernelspec": {
   "display_name": "Scala",
   "language": "scala",
   "name": "scala"
  },
  "language_info": {
   "codemirror_mode": "text/x-scala",
   "file_extension": ".sc",
   "mimetype": "text/x-scala",
   "name": "scala",
   "nbconvert_exporter": "script",
   "version": "2.13.3"
  }
 },
 "nbformat": 4,
 "nbformat_minor": 4
}
```


**Environment**

- Python Version: 3.8.3
- Output of `jupyter-book --version`:
```
$ jupyter-book --version
Jupyter Book: 0.7.4
MyST-NB: 0.8.5
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.35
MyST-Parser: 0.9.1
Jupyter-Cache: 0.3.0
```

- Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04

title: Display SVGs with hyperlinks
body:
**Describe the bug**

I would like to include an SVG image with hyperlinks on parts of the image to automatically navigate to a subsection or external website. The image is displayed but I can not click on the image to follow the links. When I open the image alone in the browser it works. I create the diagrams using [draw.io](draw.io).

**To Reproduce**

```python
from IPython.display import SVG
SVG(data='google.svg')
```
I also tried to embed the diagram directly from draw.io with the same result: The image displays but the links do not work. 
```python
from IPython.display import IFrame
src = 'https://viewer.diagrams.net/?target=self&highlight=999999&edit=_blank&layers=1&nav=1&title=Untitled%20Diagram.drawio#RdZPLbsMgEEW%2FxstGfuS5bZo6m7RSoqprAhObBnssTILdry82xg%2Bl2SA49w4MM%2BBF26yKJSnSAzIQXuizyovevDDcBKEZG1BbsAwjCxLJmUXBAE78Fzrod%2FTGGZQTo0IUihdTSDHPgaoJI1KintouKKanFiSBB3CiRDzSb85Uauk6XA18DzxJ3cnBcmOVjDhzd5MyJQz1CEU7L9pKRGVnWbUF0dTO1cXGvT9R%2B8Qk5OqfgK8S5Of5p6lJ6AtyNm1pTTG2JTRDjJiYa7bbCJ5fra61niWtMqOYWdWdidlC3V%2FFMWBwyFaKfeyP%2FCXo79LnWKra1U%2FiLWfQxPte9KpTruBUENqo2jwYw1KVNakFZnrhQmxRoGxjo8uaAqWGl0riFUbKeb2YL5oNbX53kAqqp3UZZxgDZqBkbSxdwLzrTz1d6qHbgWthOuq085HugSX9xkMPzKSriVuOuuLQ8AJa%2B%2BgbRbs%2F'
IFrame(src=src, width=700, height=600)
```
**Expected behavior**
The SVG images should display and the hyperlinks contained in them should be clickable.

**Environment**

title: Extra HTML text node created in output
body:
**Describe the bug**
Compiled pages contain an HTML text node at location `document.body.childNodes[2]` that is superfluous and looks like a mistake.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Visit one of the pages of my project, such as [this one](https://nathancarter.github.io/MA346-course-notes/_build/html/chapter-1-intro-to-data-science.html).  (Or check that book project out with `git clone https://github.com/nathancarter/MA346-course-notes.git` and then run `jupyter-book build .` in that folder and view it locally.)
2. Widen your browser view beyond the minimum required to fit the page.
3. See the erroneous HTML text element in the top left.
4. Optional: Open your browser's dev tools and find the extra HTML node at location `document.body.childNodes[2]`.

Although I linked to a specific page, the problem exists on every page of that book.

**Expected behavior**
No extraneous elements in the page.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - Python 3.7.3
 - Output of `jupyter-book --version`
```
Jupyter Book: 0.7.2
MyST-NB: 0.8.1
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.32
MyST-Parser: 0.8.1
Jupyter-Cache: 0.2.1
```

title: Navbar section numbering only renders on local build, not on web deploy

labels.name: :label: toc
labels.description: An issue related to the toc structure

body:
**Describe the bug**
In our Jupyter Book's [`_config.yml`](https://github.com/PSLmodels/Git-Tutorial/blob/master/book/_config.yml#L17) file, we set `navbar_number_sections : true` in [line 17](https://github.com/PSLmodels/Git-Tutorial/blob/master/book/_config.yml#L17) in order to put ascending numbers on each chapter in the left-side navbar. When we compile the Jupyter Book on a local machine, the chapter numbers look as expected (see first figure below). But when we commit those changes to the book's repository through pull request, the navbar chapter numbers do not render on the deployed GitHub page (see second picture below).

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Fork the book repository at [https://github.com/PSLmodels/Git-Tutorial](https://github.com/PSLmodels/Git-Tutorial)
2. Navigate to the `Git-Tutorial` top-level directory of the repository.
3. Create and activate the `conda` environment using the following commands in your terminal.
```console
$ conda env create -f environment.yml
$ conda activate jb-git-tutorial
```
4. Run the following command from your terminal to build the book.
```console
$ jb build ./book
```

**Expected behavior**
When we look at the compiled html intro page of the book on the local machine by opening the file `./_build/html/index.html` in a Google Chrome browser, the left-side navbar looks as expected. I've circled in red the navbar chapter numbers we expected.

![JupyterBook_wnums2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4317690/88727930-d6ee7600-d0ed-11ea-8c55-64d79db492c5.png)

However, when we commit this code to our book's GitHub repository [https://github.com/PSLmodels/Git-Tutorial](https://github.com/PSLmodels/Git-Tutorial), the updates are automatically compiled and deployed to the GitHub pages site [https://pslmodels.github.io/Git-Tutorial/](https://pslmodels.github.io/Git-Tutorial/) for the repository, and the navbar looks like the following image, which does not have the chapter numbers. I have circled in red the area where the navbar numbers are supposed to be and where they appeared in the local build described previously.

![JupyterBook_nonums2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4317690/88728731-968ff780-d0ef-11ea-852b-72a00360c905.png)

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
Our book's environment is specified in [`environment.yml`](https://github.com/PSLmodels/Git-Tutorial/blob/master/environment.yml)
 - Python Version is `python>=3.7.4`, but in practice I think it is `python=3.8.3`
 - Output of `jupyter-book --version`. In the environment.yml, we specify `jupyter-book>=0.7.1. The output of `jupyter-book --version` is the following:
```markdown
Jupyter Book: 0.7.1
MyST-NB: 0.8.4
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.29
MyST-Parser: 0.9.0
Jupyter-Cache: 0.2.2
```

**Additional context**
I am on the leadership council of the [PSLmodels](https://www.pslmodels.org/) (Policy Simulation Library Models) organization and on the steering committee of [QuantEcon](https://quantecon.org/). Our GitHub organization for incubating and catalogued open source policy models is [https://github.com/PSLmodels](https://github.com/PSLmodels). We are moving all of our documentation for all PSL-catalogued models to `jupyter-book`. Examples are [Tax-Calculator](https://pslmodels.github.io/Tax-Calculator/), [OG-USA](https://github.com/PSLmodels/OG-USA), and [Git-Tutorial](https://github.com/PSLmodels/Git-Tutorial) (the subject of this e-mail). We are currently incorporating GitHub Actions to deploy the `jupyter-book` GitHub pages upon commits to master, and the OG-USA `jupyter-book` documentation incorporates the Sphinx docstring scraping for the model API documentation and also deploys upon commits to master. Any help you can give us on these questions to improve our `jupyter-book` documentation will go immediately into our documentation. Thanks for such a great package.

cc: @jdebacker, @MaxGhenis, @jstac

title: Navigation breaks if iframe is the last line of a md file
body:
**Describe the bug**
When an `iframe` is the last line of a `md` file, without a trailing new line, some page navigation breaks.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. `jb create jb; cd jb`
2. Add an `iframe` to the last line of `intro.md`, e.g.:
```
<iframe src="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vQQoN_MKQqvDnUQjQHdCEISGkHYGgsSZVvHOWcv6qia260XbftP3aRh8FsPTXO-mJ8NioM7iSbNouTo/pubhtml?widget=true&headers=false"></iframe>
```
3. `jb build .`
4. Open `_build/html/intro.html`, which looks like this:

![Screenshot 2020-07-27 at 18 08 36](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6076111/88608692-36d61580-d037-11ea-8122-904cc9afecb4.png)


**Expected behavior**
This, which is produced when I add a new line to the end of the file.

![Screenshot 2020-07-27 at 18 25 42](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6076111/88608696-3c336000-d037-11ea-9990-f6514910bd35.png)


**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - Python 3.7.7
 - Output of `jupyter-book --version`:
```
Jupyter Book: 0.7.1
MyST-NB: 0.8.3
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.31
MyST-Parser: 0.8.2
Jupyter-Cache: 0.2.2
```

title: `jb toc book` will use forward slashes on windows

labels.name: :label: cli
labels.description: An issue related to the command-line interface

body:
**Describe the bug**

Using `jb toc mybook/` on a windows machine will put forward-slashes in `_toc.yml` file, while instead it should also use backslashes since Sphinx uses that across all OSes.

title: Fix typo in content-blocks.md documentation
Inconsistent treatment of H1 headers in LaTeX build

labels.name: :label: pdflatex
labels.description: Issues specific to building PDFs via latex

body:
**Describe the bug**
Some H1 headers in `.ipynb` Markdown cells are converted to LaTeX `\chapter{...}` commands and some are converted to `\section{...}` commands.  I can't seem to tell or control why/how this happens.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Choose a jupyter-book project.  I'm using [this one](https://github.com/nathancarter/MA346-course-notes).
2. Ensure that project has many different H1-type headers in it (using Markdown's `#` in `.ipynb` cells), spread over several files.
2. Run `jupyter-book build . --builder pdflatex`.
3. View the generated PDF in `./_build/latex/`. (In the above repo, it's [right here](https://github.com/nathancarter/MA346-course-notes/raw/master/_static/MA346-course-notes.pdf)).
4. The first `#` header seems to have become a chapter and all other `#` headers have become sections within it.

**Expected behavior**
Each H1 header should be treated equally, each creating its own chapter.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - Python Version 3.7.3
 - Output of `jupyter-book --version`
```
Jupyter Book: 0.7.0    # but I've tried with 0.7.2dev0 also and got the same problem
MyST-NB: 0.8.1
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.23
MyST-Parser: 0.8.1
Jupyter-Cache: 0.2.1
```

title: The navbar_number_sections option recently stopped working

labels.name: :label: pdflatex
labels.description: Issues specific to building PDFs via latex

body:
**Describe the bug**
Some change since v0.7.0 broke the `_config.yml` option `navbar_number_sections`.

**To Reproduce**
To see the behavior working correctly:
1. Create a jupyter book project with a `_config.yml` containing `navbar_number_sections: true` in the `html:` section.
2. Put some pages in.
3. Build the html *using jupyter-book v0.7.0*.
4. See the nav on the left has correctly numbered the sections.

To see the behavior working incorrectly:
1. Same as step 1 above.
2. Same as step 2 above.
3. Build the html *using jupyter-book v0.7.2dev0*.
4. See the nav on the left has not numbered the sections, ignoring the `_config.yml` setting.

**Expected behavior**
Always respect the setting in the config file.

My book repo is here: https://github.com/nathancarter/MA346-course-notes

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - Python Version 3.7.3
 - Output of `jupyter-book --version`
```
Jupyter Book: 0.7.2dev0
MyST-NB: 0.8.1
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.23
MyST-Parser: 0.8.1
Jupyter-Cache: 0.2.1
```

title: Failing tests on windows
body:
I'm trying to make a list, I'll keep editing this.

``test_build_book`` is failing because of #583: ``<script src="_static/js/myjs.js">`` is ``_static/js\myjs.js`` because the first half is added by sphinx which probably hardcoded the ``\`` and the second part is what pathlib thinks paths should look like on windows.
I wonder if we can do a simple replace but that seems hacky.

``'charmap' codec can't decode byte 0x9d in position 1589: character maps to <undefined>`` in ``test_build_docs0`` from ``test_build_docs``.

``'charmap' codec can't encode character '\u03b8' in position 196: character maps to <undefined>`` in ``test_clean_html_latex``

``C:\Users\t3kci\checkout\jupyter-book\tests\books\toc\index.md:7:toctree contains reference to nonexisting document 'subfolder\\index'`` in `` test_toc_startwithlist`` and ``test_toc_withheaders`` and ``test_toc_urllink``

title: GDPR compliance: third party CDNs
body:
**Describe the bug**
Jupyter Book depends on third party CDNs.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Create + host a book
2. Have a look at html source files or at the list of your script blocker (e.g. NoScript)
3. Jupyter Book uses resources from cloudflare.com and unpkg.com 

**Expected behavior**
Self hosted Jupyter Books should not depend on third party services. At least, there should be the possibility to opt out these external services. E.g. by statically including the JS and CSS files into the build directory.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
Not relevant.

**Additional context**
GDPR compliance is a very important / annoying topic. The current situation with third party CDNs prohibits the use of Jupyter Book for some purposes.
The issue has been satisfactorily solved in a similar project: https://github.com/squidfunk/mkdocs-material/issues/739

title: Relative paths function differently when working locally on a notebook, and when building the Jupyter book
body:
**Describe the bug**

While compiling my Jupyter book with a Jupyter notebook file inside a subfolder (e.g., the folder "3" for ch. 3) that includes the line
`df = pd.read_csv('./rt_data.csv')`
The cell runs fine when running the notebook locally. However, when I attempt to build the Jupyter Book, I get an error message (see below for full error output): `FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] File ./rt_data.csv does not exist: './rt_data.csv'`

Building the book works if I use the path relative to the repo's top level — e.g., in this case the file is in a subfolder of the book's repo called "3", so `df = pd.read_csv('./3/rt_data.csv')` works for building the book. However, this generates an error when running the notebook locally, creating challenges for development. 

Building the book works fine when I use the absolute path on my computer, however this poses two problems:
1. This book is a collaboration, so different contributors will have different absolute paths to the same files in the repo
2. It's far less clear to a reader to see an absolute path than a relative one


**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Create a Jupyter notebook with a line to read a file in CWD using `./[filename]`
2. Attempt to build the book
3. See error

**Expected behavior**
A relative path works the same when developing/running the notebook locally in Jupyter, and when building the book.

title: Math with LaTeX in figure caption is too small
body:
Hi,

**Describe the bug**
Adding maths in a figure caption (by using LaTeX syntax) works well, however it is too small to be readable.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Create a book `jb create toto`
2. Add the code for a figure in a (markdown or notebook) file, and put LaTeX code in the caption, as for example:
```
{figure} logo.png
---
height: 150px
name: my-figure
---
Here is my figure caption! Variable $\sqrt{x}$
```
(begin and end with the three quotes)
3. Build the book `jb build toto`
4. Look at the book in HTML and see that the square root of _x_ is hardly visible. 

**Expected behavior**
The size of math should be the same as the rest of the caption.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - Python 3.7.3
 - jupyter-book 0.7.0b4
- tried with Chromium and Firefox

**Additional context**
I really appreciate your job to make this tool available! As a teacher in a university, and in the context of the Covid-19 pandemy, I will flip my classrooms for the next year. Jupyter Book is amazing and I will use it to write my lectures!

title: Code tabs from sphinx-tabs don't render
body:
**Describe the bug**
When using code-tabs from the `sphinx-tabs` package:

- reStructuredText for the tabs is generated and displayed, but is not rendered
- the code is displayed within a `highlight` box but without the appropriate syntax highlighting

The tabs are rendered as:
```
.. tab:: {“tab_id”: “UHl0aG9u”, “classes”: [“code-tab”]} Python

.. code-block:: py

# Code is displayed within a highlight box here
```

I doubt that this is related, but there is 1 warning when building the minimal example book with or without tabs:
``[31;01mWARNING: unsupported theme option 'number_toc_sections' given[39;49;00m``

See this [example repo](https://github.com/best-practice-and-impact/jupyter-books-test).


**To Reproduce**
1. Add the extension:

```
sphinx:
  extra_extensions:
    - sphinx_tabs.tabs
```


2. Include code-tab syntax in a `.md` file within the book. For example:

`````
````{tabs}

```{code-tab} py

    def main():
        return

```

```{code-tab} c
int main(const int argc, const char **argv) {
    return 0;
    }
```

````
`````

3. Build the book using `jb build .`

**Expected behavior**
I expect this to render as grouped tabs, with the code syntax highlighted as appropriate.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - Python Version: 3.7.7
- sphinx-tabs: 1.1.13
- Jupyter Book: 0.7.1
- MyST-NB: 0.8.4
- Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.31
- MyST-Parser: 0.9.0
- Jupyter-Cache: 0.2.2

body:
**Describe the bug**
Hi all,
I am building a jupyter-book but some of my files are not included in the toc tree.  

**To Reproduce**

1. Go to 'https://github.com/lhoupert/from-python-to-numpy/tree/jb-version', clone the directory and ```cd jb-version```
2. Build the jupyter-book ```jupyter-book build .   ```



**Expected behavior**

My ```_toc.yml``` file is:
```yaml
- file: 00-book

- header: Get started
- file: 01-preface
- file: 02-introduction
- file: 03-anatomy

- header: Vectorization

- header: References

title: .py file in _build/jupyter_execute doesn't comment Markdown blocks, causing PEP8 issues

labels.name: state: upstream
labels.description: Requires a change to a dependant package

body:
**Describe the bug**
Building my book generated a [`.py` file](https://github.com/MaxGhenis/maxghenis.github.io/blob/7fbf744b62262fe1d860710c2394ba221a2f6f8a/jb/_build/jupyter_execute/blog/20200707/black_disability_employment.py) associated with my `.ipynb` file in the `_build/jupyter_execute` folder. This file left Markdown blocks from the notebook as normal code rather than as comments (as results from `File...Download as...Python (.py)` in Jupyter Notebook). This sets off my [style checker](https://github.com/MaxGhenis/maxghenis.github.io/pull/14#issuecomment-656989883).

**To Reproduce**
1. Add a `.ipynb` to the book
2. Build the book
3. See the `.py` file in the corresponding path of the `.ipynb` file of the `_build/jupyter` folder.

(Seems consistent, e.g. here's another [example](https://github.com/UBICenter/blog/blob/95a59bfa4085f2d0be7e88fc15a90d5e9e16c40f/jb/_build/jupyter_execute/20200707/adult_child_ubi.py)).

**Expected behavior**
Markdown blocks are commented.

**Describe the bug**

When I use dollar signs the markup reads the words in between as MathJax.  When I use \\$ to negate the MathJax and simply print the dollar signs, it prints "\$".  It shows correctly in my jupyter notebook locally but not on Jupyter Books.

title: [BUG] Using relative instead of absolute links
Binder button leading to 404
body:
**Describe the bug**
When I click the Binder button for any page in my Jupyter Book, mybinder.org tries to load the notebook but ultimately returns a '404: page not found' error.

I am new to Jupyter Books so it is entirely possible that I misunderstood the documentation for setting up Binder interactivity and that this is user error rather than a bug. Thanks in advance for your patience and understanding! Here is what I am seeing...

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to [my GitHub Pages site](https://knortheastern.github.io/onlineSpeedData-ing/Intro.html)
2. Click on the 'Binder' button
3. See '404: Not found' error
_I then took these additional steps while troubleshooting:_
4. (optional) Click on the 'Copy Binder link' button
5. (optional) Paste the copied link into your browser and navigate to it
6. (optional) Click on '_sources' and see that this is where the .ipynb files are
7. (optional) Click on 'Intro.ipynb' and see that it loads successfully

**Expected behavior**
Clicking on the 'Binder' button would lead to mybinder.org successfully loading the notebook for any page in the book.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
Jupyter Book: 0.7.0
MyST-NB: 0.8.3
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.27
MyST-Parser: 0.9.0
Jupyter-Cache: 0.2.2

**Additional context**
 I am using ghp-import and gh-pages to build my site. I initially tried to add interactivity with these settings in my config.yml:

```markdown
repository:
  url: https://github.com/KNortheastern/onlineSpeedData-ing  # Online location of your book
  branch: gh-pages

launch_buttons:
  thebelab: true
  binderhub_url: "https://mybinder.org"  # The URL for your BinderHub (e.g., https://mybinder.org)
```
When that didn't work, I tried specifying the 'book_path' in an attempt to guide mybinder.org to the _sources folder that I could see contained the .ipynb files, like so:
```markdown
repository:
  url: https://github.com/KNortheastern/onlineSpeedData-ing  # Online location of your book
  branch: gh-pages
  book_path: _sources

launch_buttons:
  thebelab: true
  binderhub_url: "https://mybinder.org"  # The URL for your BinderHub (e.g., https://mybinder.org)
```

Neither of these configurations seemed to fix the 404 error. Could someone please tell me what I'm doing wrong?

Thanks!

title: Binder: Spec is not of the form "user/repo/ref"
body:
**Describe the bug**
Pressing the `Binder` or the `Thebelab` button both result in the same error, which is 
```
Binder: Spec is not of the form "user/repo/ref", provided: "cedeerwe/test_book". Did you mean "cedeerwe/test_book/master"?
```

**To Reproduce**
1. Build a book using the standard `jb build test-book`. 
2. Deploy the book to `gh-pages` using the command from the docs `ghp-import -n -p -f test-book/_build/html`. The page is rendered correctly, as seen [here](https://cedeerwe.github.io/test_book/hazard/02_sestka3.html).
3. Press the `Thebelab` or `Binder` buttons. Binder results in a 400 error, while Thebelab gets stuck at `waiting for kernel` with the error described above in the console.

**Expected behavior**
Thebelab and binder would be launched with the correct `user/repo/ref` form.

**Link to repo**
https://github.com/cedeerwe/test_book

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - Python 3.6.9
 - Output of `jupyter-book --version`
```
Jupyter Book: 0.7.0
MyST-NB: 0.8.3
Sphinx Book Theme: 0.0.25
MyST-Parser: 0.8.2
Jupyter-Cache: 0.2.2
```

**Additional context**
I remember `Thebelab` having an issue already about a month ago, but I am not sure whether this was the same problem.

title: Repository button cannot be hidden
body:
**Describe the bug**
Update to jupyter-book==0.7.0b4.
The repository button still appears in HTML while I set `use_repository_button` to `false` in _config.yaml.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. On a terminal: `jb create toto`
2. Add at the end of _config.yaml the following lines:

```
html:
  favicon                   : ""  # A path to a favicon image
  navbar_number_sections    : false  # Add a number to each section in your left navbar
  use_edit_page_button      : false  # Whether to add an "edit this page" button to pages. If `true`, repository information in repository: must be filled in
  use_repository_button     : false  # Whether to add a link to your repository button
```

3. On a terminal: `jb build toto`
4. The 'GitHub' button still appears, with the default link to the JupyterBook GitHub repository

**Expected behavior**
The 'GitHub' button should not appear.

**My actual _config.yaml**
```
# Book settings
title: My sample book
author: The Jupyter Book Community
logo: logo.png

latex:
  latex_documents:
    targetname: book.tex

html:
  favicon                   : ""  # A path to a favicon image
  navbar_number_sections    : false  # Add a number to each section in your left navbar
  use_edit_page_button      : false  # Whether to add an "edit this page" button to pages. If `true`, repository information in repository: must be filled in
  use_repository_button     : false  # Whether to add a link to your repository button
```

**Environment :**
- Ubuntu 18.04
 - Python 3.7.3
 - `jupyter-book --version` return an error: `Error: no such option: --version`
- with `pip freeze` I get `jupyter-book==0.7.0b4`

title: Unable to import local modules in the Book
body:
**Describe the bug**
Unable to import local modules in the Book

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to the repo , to 'gh-pages' and clone it : https://github.com/leilaicruz/SATAY-jupyter-book/tree/gh-pages
2. Activate wintest , the conda environment in `environment_win.yml`
3. `runjb mini_book/docs`
4. See error `[1;31mModuleNotFoundError[0m: No module named 'chromosome_and_gene_positions'
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'chromosome_and_gene_positions'`

**Expected behavior**
I expect that the file named : `gene_reads.md` is able to import the modules that require inside the `python_modules` folder, where I have this code, that works in the notebook:
```python
file_dirname = os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath('__file__'))

title: dependency to jupyter_client needs a tweak
body:
**Describe the bug**

I just received following exception when running `jupyter-book create`

```
ImportError: cannot import name 'secure_write' from 'jupyter_core.paths' (/Users/tparment/miniconda3/envs/flotpython-slides/lib/python3.7/site-packages/jupyter_core/paths.py)
```

**My fix**

following [an advice that I found about the same exception in another context](https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/issues/5014), I ran

```
pip install -U jupyter_client
```

which - somehow - issued only this

```
ERROR: nbclient 0.3.1 has requirement nbformat>=5.0, but you'll have nbformat 4.4.0 which is incompatible.
Installing collected packages: jupyter-core
  Found existing installation: jupyter-core 4.5.0
    Uninstalling jupyter-core-4.5.0:
      Successfully uninstalled jupyter-core-4.5.0
Successfully installed jupyter-core-4.6.3
```

and from then on I could successfully run the initial book creation command

**Comments**

Unfortunately I have not a complete capture of `pip freeze` before the upgrade

All along I was using this:
```
pip show jupyter-book
Name: jupyter-book
Version: 0.7.0b4
```

It feels like some dependency could be improved somewhere, sorry that I can't be more specific

 - Python Version [3.7.1]

This is my build.yml
```
name: Test Build
on:
  push:
    branches-ignore:
      - master
jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout 🛎️
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

          persist-credentials: false

© 2020 GitHub, Inc.

title: editing toc does not cause a rebuild
body:
**Describe the bug**

Modifying `_toc.yml` (adding or removing items) does not trigger a rebuild.

**To Reproduce**

1. `jupyter-book create test`
2. `cd test ; jupyter-book build .`
3. Edit `_toc.yml` by commenting out a single toc entry.
4. Execute `jupyter-book build .`
5. Observe that no rebuild of html files is triggered, and toc is still old.

**Expected behavior**

The html files are rebuilt with toc updated.

title: incorrect initial permissions on example book

labels.name: :label: cli
labels.description: An issue related to the command-line interface

body:
The example book created by `jupyter-book create` creates files with permissions 775. None of these files are really executable, and therefore the correct permissions should be 664 (or probably 644)

**To Reproduce**

`jupyter-book create test; ls -al test`

title: Apostrophes in myst are convered to backticks in the generated tex document

labels.name: :label: pdflatex
labels.description: Issues specific to building PDFs via latex

body:
**Describe the bug**
I don't know whether it is a bug or not. But all apostrophes in the original Jupyter notebook's markdown content are converted to backticks in the generated tex document and then to weird characters in the pdf. I have to manually replace the backticks by apostrophes in the tex document and run pdflatex to get the proper outcome. This does not happen with HTML output.

**To Reproduce**
Just type apostrophes in a jupyter-notebook's markdown cell and build with pdflatex.

**Expected behavior**
Apostrophes' appearancce should keep the same across markdown, latex and pdf documents

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - Python Version [3.6.9]
 - Package Version [0.7.0b3]

**Additional context**

title: MathJax \begin{align} rendered as a single line equation
body:
**Describe the bug**
I have a \begin{align} environment in my markdown file to create multiline equations. However, the equations are rendered in a single line. I have used the same source code in a Jupyter Notebook and it works as expected:
https://github.com/bsamadi/cvxguide/blob/master/cvxguide.ipynb

By the way, GitHub rendering has the same issue. I have used the same source in a post made by Hugo and rendered by MathJax 3. It works:
http://www.mechatronics3d.com/post/2014-convex-optimization/

Also, Jupyter can render the same LaTeX problem properly. The issue might be fixed if MathJax 3 is used. My Hugo website uses MathJax 3 and the formula is rendered properly on the MathJax website (online demo).

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior, see this page:
https://bsamadi.github.io/cvxguide/ConvexOptimization.html

The source code is:
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bsamadi/cvxguide/master/cvxguidebook/ConvexOptimization.md

**Expected behavior**
The result of the \begin{align}\end{align} environment is multiline equations.

title: BUG: jupyter-book build of docs fails using pdflatex builder due unsupported mimetypes
body:
**Describe the bug**

The `docs` build fails when compiling using the `pdflatex` builder due the presence of `gif` and `svg` files. Warnings are issued by sphinx and are issued by [sphinx/builders/__init__.py](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/blob/302c23fb5c172826499e8b3fb6d9eccd3c32d307/sphinx/builders/__init__.py#L195) but it doesn't `raise SkipNode` so only a `warning` is issued

```
/jupyter-book/docs/content-types/markdown.md:: WARNING: a suitable image for latex builder not found: ['image/gif'] (https://media.giphy.com/media/yoJC2A59OCZHs1LXvW/giphy.gif)
```

but no action is taken so a `gif` file is still written to the tex file as:

```latex
\sphinxincludegraphics{{jupyter-book/docs/_build/.doctrees/images/7263dbd03e523cb3d81ae3fc5e19e56ae1ecd55a/giphy}.gif}
```

and `latex` compilation fails using `pdflatex`. 

So after playing with refactoring [myst-nb/transform.py](https://github.com/executablebooks/MyST-NB/blob/master/myst_nb/transform.py#L53) and [cell_output_to_nodes in juypyter-sphinx](https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter-sphinx/blob/6a0df8575fd1fc76e1258aab300ec415eee92569/jupyter_sphinx/ast.py#L230) by adding a builder context:

```python
if builder == "latex" and "gif" in mime_type:
                    logger.warning(
                        "[%s] doesn't support object of mime type: %s".format(builder, mime_type)
                    )
                    to_add.append(
                        docutils.nodes.SkipNode
                    )
```

it doesn't seem to get called as `myst_nb` (and therefore `jupyter-sphinx`) code doesn't appear to execute for `gif` (but using `pdb` it does for `png`). It seems like `sphinx` skips the transform and `SkipNode` can't be actioned by myst_nb to fix this so I am unsure of how to proceed on this one.

**To Reproduce**

Trying to fix the current test failure when building `docs` in `jupyter-book`

title: Tables are not rendered
body:
**Describe the bug**

A markdown table, rendered in Jupyter, does not get rendered in the jupyter-book output.

```markdown
| Quantity            | Name               | Unit|
| ------------------ :| ----------------- :| -- :|
|  Length             |  millimeter        | mm  |
|  Time               |  nanosecond        | ns  |
|  Energy             |  Mega electron Volt| MeV |
|  Positron charge    |  eplus             |     |
|  Temperature        |  kelvin            | K   |
|  Amount of substance|  mole              | mol |
|  Luminous intensity |  candela           | cd  |
| Plane angle         |  radian            | rad |
|  Solid angle        |  steradian         | sr  |
```

Gets rendered as this:

| Quantity            | Name               | Unit|
| ------------------ :| ----------------- :| -- :|
|  Length             |  millimeter        | mm  |
|  Time               |  nanosecond        | ns  |
|  Energy             |  Mega electron Volt| MeV |
|  Positron charge    |  eplus             |     |
|  Temperature        |  kelvin            | K   |
|  Amount of substance|  mole              | mol |
|  Luminous intensity |  candela           | cd  |
| Plane angle         |  radian            | rad |
|  Solid angle        |  steradian         | sr  |

```console
$ jupyter book build mybook
ERROR ...
```

I should have a live example at some point soon, my GitHub-actions is broken (jupyter-book + conda worked beautifully, pushing to GitHub is not working)

PS: You can type `juptyer book` instead of `jupyter-book`; just like `git` does, the Jupyter command delegates to programs with dashes in the path. Might be more memorable for users, don't know. :)

title: Docs binder hub duplicate?
body:
The [docs page](https://jupyterbook.org/customize/config.html) has this:

# Configure your Binder links, such as the URL of the BinderHub.
binder:

```

which seems to conflict with this, a little further down on the page:

launch_buttons:

```

Also, quotes around URLs and strings are inconsistent on the page. I mildly prefer not having them, since it's allowed. But all in quotes is valid too.

title: Navigation with non-english characters (Table of Contents)
body:
**Summary of the problem:**
Section names with non-ascii letters cannot be linked from the table of code and everything points at a problem with *turbolinks* [turbolinks project page](https://github.com/turbolinks/turbolinks).

**Full description:**
My native language is not English and I'm currently writing a non-English project. During this project I've encountered a problem that may have eluded you in your tests, and that I haven't been able to figure out.

Occasionally, I've got section names with characters that do not belong on the English alphabet. In particular, in Spanish we've got accents on vowels ( á, é, í, ó, ú and the letter ñ) and they are extremely frequent. The problem I have is that the Page Navigation on the sidebar is not working for sections that have one of these special characters in their title: when I click on the section name, the browser jumps to the top of the page, as if it wasn't recognizing the anchor.

You can see a live example [here](https://cupi2-ip.github.io/IPBook/nivel1/seccion1-2.html), where the link to the subsection "Intérprete" is not working. Something interesting to noting is that the link in the menu points to "#Intérprete", but when I copy the link and paste  it in the browser it replaces the non-ascii characters and it becomes "#Int%C3%A9rprete".

I created a minimal page to test if non-ascii characters were valid in HTML anchors and I found out that they do! I was able to link "#Intérprete" and get the browser to jump to that part of the page. Then I pasted everything from a typical Jupyter Book <head> into my minimal example and the link stopped working. In the end I was able to find that when *turbolink* is included, non-ascii characters in the anchors stop working. These are the offending lines:

```javascript
  <!-- Include Turbolinks to make page loads fast -->
  <!-- https://github.com/turbolinks/turbolinks -->
  <script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/turbolinks/5.2.0/turbolinks.js" async></script>
```
As I said, removing this library solves the problem but I have not been able to figure out:

1. why the problem is happening, 
2. what's the actual problem (I don't really understand what is wrong with the links), 
3. how to force the removal of turbolinks from my book, 
3. what could be the consequences of removing it. 

I did not found any information or any issue reported in turbolinks repository about potential problems with non-ascii characters.

title: Problem with the migration of books to 0.6.3
body:
Hello,

I just encountered a very weird problem with a book that I upgraded from **0.5.1 to 0.6.3**

I always used `deploy.sh` to build the book and when I upgraded my local installation of jupyter-books it required me to migrate the book to the new version. I did it apparently without problems, but from then on it was impossible to me to see changes on my deployed **github pages** books.

I think I just discovered the root of the issue: inside my old `_build` folder I had old .md files. Thus, every time I changed my source in `content`, either the **gh pages** system or my local jekyll were ignoring the changes and using the outdated .md file.

I guess this can be fixed in the migration script if it deletes the .md files from the `_build` folder.

title: Hosting Book on Apache Webserver
body:
Dear Jupyter-book devs,

thanks for the effort in creating this tool, it looks like can be very useful for teaching and providing internal research reports.

I've been trying to find a way to build and deploy a basic book to one of our internal servers. The Webserver is based on Apache. In principle, I get a folder in my home directory:

```
$ ls /home/csys/pgierz/public_html
index.html
... other html files ...
Teaching/
```

These can be seen in a browser under the following address when in our internal network:
```
http://paleosrv1.awi.de/~pgierz/index.html
```

I had hoped the following would work. In `_config.yml`:

```
baseurl: /Teaching/Animations  # the subpath of your site, e.g. /blog. If there is no subpath for your site, use an empty string ""
url: http://paleosrv1.awi.de/~pgierz # the base hostname & protocol for your site, e.g. http://example.com
```
When I then copy the result of `make site` to the appropriate folder, I keep getting 404 errors since I'm redirected to the basic site (`http://paleosrv1.awi.de/Teaching/Animations`, and not `http://paleosrv1.awi.de/~pgierz/Teaching/Animations`)

Changing `baseurl` to `/~pgierz/Teaching/Animations` also doesn't seem to help. Any hints would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks,
Paul

title: Don't use quotes for user-entered YAML entries
body:
Because we used to wrap page title entries with quotes in YAML
front-matter, pages with a quote in the name would cause Jekyll to error
out ([like this page titled "What's in a name?"][1]).

This commit uses [YAML Block Scalars][2] to give users the greatest
flexibility when naming book sections. Section names can now contain
single quotes, double quotes, and colons.

To test this:

1. I edited `jupyter_book/book_template/_data/toc.yml`, changing the
   page titled `Jupyter notebooks` to `"Sam's Cool Title: Notebooks!"`.
   I verified that building the website does not break at either
   `jupyter-book build` or the `jekyll build` step.
2. I opened http://127.0.0.1:4001/jupyter-book/features/notebooks.html
   and verified that the sidebar had the updated title.
3. I opened http://127.0.0.1:4001/jupyter-book/features/hiding.html and
   verified that the previous page button at the bottom of the page had
   `Sam's Cool Title: Notebooks!` as the previous page's title.

[1]: https://www.textbook.ds100.org/ch/01/lifecycle_students_3.html
[2]: http://blogs.perl.org/users/tinita/2018/03/strings-in-yaml---to-quote-or-not-to-quote.html

title: Set a blank excerpt for all pages
body:
This commit sets a blank Jekyll excerpt as the default for all pages
([docs on excerpts][1]). Without this configuration, Jekyll tries to
generate a page excerpt using the first paragraph of each page. However,
we do not use the page excerpt anywhere in this project (since we don't
have an equivalent of a "list of all blog posts" page). Setting a blank
excerpt decreases website build time.

More importantly, in a later commit I plan to wrap HTML generated from a
Jupyter notebook in a `{% raw %}` tag ([docs][2]). Without this tag,
complicated LaTeX will break Jekyll builds. However, when Jekyll tries
to generate page excerpts, it breaks because the excerpt contains the
`{% raw %}` tag but not the `{% endraw %}` tag.

[1]: https://jekyllrb.com/docs/posts/#post-excerpts
[2]: https://shopify.github.io/liquid/tags/raw/

title: fixing footer width
body: Fixes the footer width so it's centered

title: Links to notebooks from within a notebook will break
body:
In #198 @psychemedia pointed out that any links within a notebook that point to another notebook will be broken in the built site. This is because the ipynb will be converted to HTML (and in some cases, the names would be sanitized).

This seems confusing for many readers, though I am unsure what the "optimal" outcome is here. It could be one of:

1. The inter-content links to ipynb files are automatically converted to `html` files with a simple find/replace (however, what if people *want* to link to a notebook and not its HTML version?)
2. We could copy over the raw notebooks into the content folder in the final built site so that they exist relative to the HTML pages.

title: Some small formatting issues following upgrade to master
body:
Sorry for opening and closing issues but get getting familiar with this project!  I noticed that my book (and others) has a fixed width in Safari such that the entire page is centered in the browser and only expands to some maximum width (about 1200px).  In contrast the example book, the table of contents anchor to the left side of the page and the main text area expands to fill whatever space is available.  This seems to somewhat influence if you can do the Tufts-Style pullouts.  Is there a way to toggle the behavior that the jupyterbook guide has?

Example: 
Fixed width: http://www.pymc-learn.org/pymc-learn-book/features/interact
Left anchor, scaling width: https://jupyter.org/jupyter-book/intro.html

title: Use CDNs for JS libraries
body:
This commit uses CDNs to serve five JS libraries that are currently
checked into this repo:

    anchor.min.js
    lunr/lunr.min.js
    print.min.js
    tocbot.min.js
    turbolinks.js

The corresponding copies of these libraries in this repo are removed.

It's considered good practice to use CDNs to serve minified JS files
since CDNs are designed to serve static files fast.

This doesn't change page load time for me, but might have benefits for
people located outside California (where there are fewer GitHub
servers and more Cloudflare servers).

title: Load thebelab asynchronously
body:
Adds an `async` attribute to the script tag to load thebelab
asynchronously. This allows the DOM to load while loading thebelab in
the background.

How I tested this:

1. Load
   http://127.0.0.1:4000/jupyter-book/01/3/Plotting_the_Classics.html
2. Hard refresh the page. This results in an average DOMContentLoaded
   time of 1.1s.
3. Add `async` attribute and hard refresh the page again. This results
   in an average DOMContentLoaded time of 660ms, a 40% speedup.
4. To verify that this still loads thebelab, I ran a few cells on this
   page using thebelab after loading asynchronously.

title: Fix missing if page.interact_link is false
body: Before, setting page.interact_link = false would result in a missing `` tag which caused lots of problems for page layout. This PR ensures that the `` always appears. Without the fix: With the fix:

title: Simple Template Repository for creating new Jupyter Books
body:
I've been getting in a muddle again thinking about how to create a simple workflow for creating new Jupyter Books.

I'm a complete novice at CI, so what I've started trying to sketch out a thought experiment, using a basic repo with a minimal structure s/thing like:

```
.circleci/config.yml #automation
content/ #content files
_config.yml #jupyterbook config
requirements.txt #required packages for notebook execution
```

In the first part, I imagine creating a simple Jupyter book, perhaps in a new branch:

- install `jupyter-book` and other requirements as specified in `requirements.txt`
- create a Jupyter Book from files provided in `content/` with an automatically generated table of contents and using the supplied Jupyter Book configuration.

```
version: 2
jobs:
  fetch_and_commit:
    docker:
      - image: circleci/python:3.6.4
    steps:
      - checkout
      #- restore_cache:
      # Read about caching dependencies: https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/caching/
      #    key: dependencies-{{ .Branch }}-{{ checksum "requirements.txt" }}
      - run:
          name: create virtualenv
          command: |
            python -m virtualenv env
      - run:
          command: |
            . env/bin/activate
            pip install -r requirements.txt
      #- save_cache: 
      #    paths:
      #      - ./env
      #    key: dependencies-{{ .Branch }}-{{ checksum "requirements.txt" }}     
      - run:
          command: |
            . env/bin/activate
            
            # Build the book in branch: jupyterbook
            git checkout -b jupyterbook
            
            # Should we perhaps delete any pre-existing buildbook dir?
            # Does --overwrite get rid of the specified dir first or just add files to it?
            jupyter-book create --content-folder content --config _config.yml --overwrite buildbook

            jupyter-book toc buildbook
            jupyter-book build buildbook/
            
            git add buildbook/*
            
            git config --global user.email "jupyterbookbot@example.com"
            git config --global user.name "jupyterbookbot"
            git commit -m "Autobuild..." && \
              git push -q https://${GITHUB_PERSONAL_TOKEN}@github.com/USER/REPO.git jupyterbook \
              || true

workflows:
  version: 2
  build:
    jobs:
      - fetch_and_commit:
          filters:
            branches:
              only:
                - master
```
In the second part, automation will then:

- generate the Jekyll site in `gh-pages` from the Jupyter book branch using the `config.yml`. I'm guessing that a huge chunk of https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter-book/blob/master/.circleci/config.yml would be relevant to this?

What I'm looking for is a minimal template repo that would only require a user to:

- set up a CircleCI account and add a Github personal token to it as an environment variable;
- add content to the `content` dir;
- provide settings in the Jupyter Book `_config.yml` (along with any other asset files, eg branding logos, specified therein);
- configure their Github repo to serve a Github Pages site from the `gh-pages` branch.

*If things like bibliographies etc require a separate directory / specific filename, then this should be part of the template repo as an empty file.*

Ideally, a user should then be able to edit markdown / py / ipynb files in the content directory and then let Jupyter Book (using Jupytext & nbconvert) generate output files as required.

It might be even simpler if the content were not in the `content` directory but instead was at the repo top level, perhaps with the `_config.yml` and `requirements.txt` somewhere obvious but out of the way, eg in a `_jupyter-book-config` directory?

For folk who don't use Github, then even the branches may be a bit confusing, in which case we should probably have the content files in eg `content`, the Jupyter Book markdown files built into `_build` and the final published site into eg `docs`, which then becomes the path that Github Pages uses to publish the site? I was thinking, though, that separating machine from author generated files by using different branches may make the workflow easier / less likely to confuse an author.

title: fixing jupytext markdown inconsistencies
body:
This changes the logic for reading in text files in order to be more consistent about how markdown files are handled.

The current situation:

Any content file will be read in with jupytext. This is awesome, with the exception that some people's code **blocks** may be incorrectly parsed as code **cells** in the markdown files. In the short term, it'd be tricky to avoid that behavior from within juyptext

This PR's approach:

If a `.markdown` or `.md` file is found, read it in to memory. First see if it has any YAML header.

* If so, check if `yaml.get('jupyter').get('jupytext')` returns None.
    * If so, or if there was no YAML, then assume it is a "regular" markdown file and just dump it into a single NotebookNode markdown cell. 
    * If not (AKA, there's something in `yaml.jupyter.jupytext`) then use `jupytext.reads` to load in the notebook.

The main assumption this is making is that jupytext files will always have a YAML header with something in the `jupyter.jupytext` field, while non-jupytext markdown files will not. That seems like a reasonable assumption to make.

@mwouts what do you think about this implementation? It's a bit hacky, but at least in the short-term it solves the markdown parsing differences problem. Perhaps longer-term we can figure out a way to solve this more gracefully!

title: 'jupyter-book upgrade' deletes new references
body:
Hi!

When running the command `jupyter-book upgrade` using the latest version of jupyter-book directly downloaded from the github repo, I noticed that in the upgraded book all my references (stored in the folder `_bibliography`) were deleted and replaced with the default ones. 

When tracking down the error, I realized that the script [create.py](https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter-book/blob/master/jupyter_book/commands/create.py) is not copying the references folder from the old book to the upgraded book, but it’s actually copying the references folder from the template book (thus erasing newly added information).

To find a possible solution, I added a few lines of code to `create.py` to:

1) Ignore the `_bibliography` folder when copying the template book:
```
    ignore_folders = ['_build', 'content', '_bibliography']
```
2) Add an argument called `‘bib_folder’` to the `new_book` function and inside it copy the references from the old book to the upgraded book:
```
    _check_file_exists(bib_folder)
    print("Copying over your bibliography folder...")
    sh.copytree(bib_folder, op.join(path_out, '_bibliography'))
```

With these changes added, I re-ran the upgrade process and the references didn’t get deleted.

If you can replicate this problem and you think this could be a possible solution (with improvements), I could submit a PR with the changes.

title: Problems with local build instructions on Mac (and perhaps other 'nix platforms)
body:
It turns out that the instructions for doing local builds ( at least on a Mac) don't work. The steps I've gone through so far to make progress (with links to some of the relevant roadblocks) are:

+ Install command line tools (`xcode-select --install`) (may not be necessary depending on how recent your last OS update was).
+ Update `gem` itself (see [this in-progress update to the jupyter-book instructions](https://github.com/mwcraig/jupyter-book/commit/a9f9d62af61f6b819eee82b3ca83685e5acb8d95), which includes a link to a [statement from the bundler folks](https://bundler.io/blog/2019/01/04/an-update-on-the-bundler-2-release.html) and an [answer on stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/a/54118329)). **THIS IS NOT MAC-SPECIFIC**
+ Install the conda compilers for mac: `conda install clangxx_osx-64` (see https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47314899/how-to-avoid-clang-no-such-file-or-directory-error). **My hunch is that something like this is needed on linux too.**
+ On 10.14/Mojave, make the standard headers show up in the standard places because [apple just had to move them](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/9050#issuecomment-424417456).

Once that stuff is done, `make install` proceeds much farther, until it gets to building `eventmachine`, which uses openssl, and it can't find the headers for that:

```
./project.h:119:10: fatal error: 'openssl/ssl.h' file not found
#include <openssl/ssl.h>
         ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
```

That led me to [this anaconda issue](https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues/issues/9863) about building gems. I tried the monkey patch at https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues/issues/9863#issuecomment-460512146 but it didn't do the trick for me.

Will continue trying for a little bit longer and report back if I get something to work.

title: thebelab always runs in home directory
body:
Currently, thebelab always runs in the home directory. It would be really convenient, if it were started in the subdirectory of the current page, e.g. `contents/chapter_X`.  This way I could add chapter-dependent code files in this subdirectory. This would also fit with the current behavior of the "interact" button.

I wonder if this would be possible by modifying this line using the current page's data?

https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter-book/blob/493b346d888ee7c863d93c73abb53f038a54a89c/jupyter_book/book_template/_includes/js/thebelab.html#L8

title: Thebelab kernel not changing between languages when browsing between pages
body:
Original post/problem below.

There is currently a bug that causes the Thebelab kernel config setting (`kernel_name`) to not be refreshed/changes relative to the initial page the user accessed the Jupyter Book on. 

This issue was discovered (for me) because the initial landing page in the template ([content/intro.md](https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter-book/blob/8e5eeed29db7a94862579d166fbf66cec0226b32/content/intro.md)) is not an ipynb, so when the ([_build/intro.md](https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter-book/blob/8e5eeed29db7a94862579d166fbf66cec0226b32/_build/intro.md)) file is built, the `kernel_name` config value is not set. Due to a [recent contribution](https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter-book/blame/47473b4b6a24bf078519e0e627b2e018d28866dd/_includes/js/thebelab.html#L10-L12), pages with no `kernel_name` set in their configs start Thebelab using python3. So for me, since all my notebooks were not using the python3 kernel (I was using SoS) , every user landing on the home page *first* were not using the right kernel to run the Jupyter Notebooks later one when browsing the other pages. A page reload would fix this issue (if on a page that was build using an ipynb), presumably because this would clear the cache and initiate a new Thebelab session (this time, on a page that has the proper `kernel_name` setup).

(original post)

I'm not sure which tool is the culprit here, so I'll start by posting my issue here at the top and work my way down.

I'm using Jupyter Book, the Thebelab feature, MyBinder, a Dockerfile, and the Jupyter Notebooks are running on the Script of Scripts kernel for multi-language support.

This issue is reproducible, I've done it several times in a row. It happens for other UX "pathways", not all, but for the sake of simplicity I will describe the simplest here.

The gist of the issue is that, the first time a user (that's me!) loads a Jupyter Book chapter, then tries to run a Thebelab cell, the magic command at the top of the cell (used/required by the Script of Scripts Jupyter kernel to indicate which language needs to be used for that cell, e.g. `%use octave`, `%use sos` (actually means python3)) is either not executed, not recognized, or something else. Or, the jupyter book isn't opened using the SoS kernel. This causes an error (for my case, since the first cell is some Octave/Matlab code, the an error is thrown I think because it still thinks it's in a python environment and can't read the Matlab syntax).

**HOWEVER**, if I simply immediately reload the web page, and follow the same steps, the kernel is loaded fine, and the cells execute without issue.

I took two videos of me reproducing this issue:

Video 1: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aeiB_LB2Q6w&feature=youtu.be

Video 2: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P0B9Zqr886Y&feature=youtu.be

Note that, I don't encounter this behaviour if I try running the cells within a separate MyBinder session (not Thebelab).

To replicate the steps exactly:

1 - Start at the landing page : https://qmrlab.org/t1_book
2 - Click the "Signal Modelling" page under "Inversion Recovery"
3 - Click the "Interact Inline" button.
4 - Go down to the first cell (starts with `%use octave`), and click run
5 - (optional) Since the first cell isn't supposed to have any output and only the second one does, click run on the second cell too (starts with `%use sos`)
6 - You should have encountered errors for both cells.
7 - Immediately reload the page.
8 - Follow steps 3-5, and a plotly figure should appear after the second cell after a minute or so.

Repo: https://github.com/qMRLab/t1_book
Github is setup to generate the site off of the gh-pages branch: https://github.com/qMRLab/t1_book/tree/gh-pages

title: Table header issue of R dataframe from Jupyter R notebook
body:
I'm currently developing a Jupter book using this wonderful project. However I'm running into one issue with table rendering in Jupyter R notebook. 

## Problem

The table header are messed up in the HTML output:

![2019-01-07-10-47-33_scrot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/917985/50780967-ea1ac600-1269-11e9-93cf-183ac2c665d7.png)

## Reproducing it

To save you the efforts reproducing the issue please find attached the relevant section from the intermediate markdown file exported by the build script into the `_build` folder:

[R_dataframe_output.md.txt](https://github.com/choldgraf/jupyter-book/files/2733527/R_dataframe_output.md.txt)

The `<div markdown="0" class="output output_html">` in question was automatically generated from Jupyter notebook. 

## Software versions

1. 
```
> jupyter-notebook --version
5.6.0
```
2. `jupyter-book` version: the current `master`. 

Please let me know if you need more information. Looking forward to hearing from you!

title: Differences in math rendering with the Jupyter Notebook
body: From @dcroce: When opening the ipython notebook, the math shows up slightly different. For example the \ to escape the * will show up in the ipython notebook but on the textbook turns out as desired. There are other minor differences too. See 9.3 of the textbook and compare to the notebook for a specific example (New url is http://prob140.org/textbook/chapters/README)
